# 保持警惕，應對風浪

2024年，金管局在錯綜複雜的外部環境中迎難而上。年內，區域性軍事衝突不斷、多國舉行重要的選舉，全球經濟走向欠明朗，令世界局勢持續震盪。然而，各地的決策者在控制通脹飈升和支持經濟發展之間尋求適當平衡，推動主要經濟體實現穩健增長。此外，隨着美國啟動四年來首次減息，加上內地連串支持經濟的政策出台，令市場情緒轉趨樂觀。整體而言，全球宏觀環境仍充滿變數。

面對複雜形勢，我們的應對策略是繼續充分發揮香港離岸人民幣業務、金融科技與綠色和可持續金融的樞紐作用和獨特優勢，持續鞏固香港國際金融中心的領先地位。2024年，金管局在這些重點領域取得顯著進展。年度盛事「國際金融領袖投資峰會」等多項活動和計劃反應熱烈，充分展現出國際社會對香港國際金融中心發展前景的堅定信心。

面對香港經濟的周期性調整和結構性轉型，我們與銀行界緊密合作，加強對中小型企業（中小企）的支援，紓緩企業在高息環境下的還款負擔，同時助力它們持續發展。加上中央和香港特區政府推出的多項政策措施，香港經濟得以穩步復甦。2024年，本港經濟錄得2.5%的溫和增長。

踏入2025年，全球經濟在更趨複雜的地緣政治形勢下繼續面臨諸多不確定性。貿易保護主義升温和關稅壁壘增加，將導致全球供應鏈受阻，地緣經濟割裂加劇，為全球經濟前景增添更多變數。倘若地緣政治緊張局勢進一步升溫，將可能對實體經濟和環球金融市場造成雙重衝擊。

面對複雜嚴峻的經濟和金融環境，金管局將保持警惕，切實履行我們的職責，竭力維護香港貨幣與銀行體系穩定，並持續鞏固香港國際金融中心地位。我們將深化與市場各界的聯繫，積極推動新興領域的發展，確保香港在全球金融格局中保持領先優勢。

# 聯繫匯率制度：穩健基石

聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）實施40多年來，一直是香港貨幣與金融穩定的基石，成功抵禦了多個經濟和利率周期的挑戰，展現出強大的抗震力。

儘管2024年美國利率政策充滿不確定性，但港元貨幣市場繼續按照聯匯制度的機制暢順運行。年內港元滙率在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的兌換範圍內上落，在年初首四個月因流動性回軟而稍為走弱，其後逐步轉強，至年底時接近強方兌換保證水平。穩定的匯率充分反映了市場對聯匯制度的信心。同時聯匯制度亦持續獲得國際貨幣基金組織及國際金融界的高度認可。

市場對聯匯制度的信心，建基於我們持續主動向公眾闡釋聯匯制度的運作機制和優點，以及嚴密的市場監察工作。通過收集詳細數據，結合先進的數據分析和人工智能技術，我們對市場進行更及時、更全面的監察和金融穩定性評估。

# 銀行體系：多重挑戰下保持穩健

2024年，香港銀行體系在多重宏觀挑戰下展現出強大的韌性，資本和流動性保持充裕。2024年底，本地銀行綜合總資本比率達21.8%，高於8%的國際最低要求。流動性方面亦同樣充裕，第4季度大型銀行流動性覆蓋比率達178.4%，高於100%的法定最低門檻。受利率持續高企、部分內地房企債務問題尚未完全緩解，以及本地商業房地產市場疲弱等因素影響，特定分類貸款比率於年底上升至1.96%。由於銀行恪守審慎的信用風險管理並維持充足撥備，相關風險總體可控。

在持續密切監察銀行信貸風險包括物業按揭貸款相關風險的同時，金管局針對物業市場狀況及銀行體系相關風險的變化，於2024年對物業按揭貸款的逆周期宏觀審慎監管措施實施了兩輪調整。具體而言，所有住宅物業的最高按揭成數及供款與入息比率上限均回復至2009年實施逆周期宏觀審慎措施前的水平。

在持續強化銀行信貸風險管理的同時，我們亦致力提升銀行的運作與科技穩健性，應對日益依賴第三方服務提供者所帶來的新挑戰。以去年7月的CrowdStrike全球事故為例，該事故凸顯了在當今全球高度連繫的環境下，運作故障可能造成連鎖的嚴重後果。雖然事故對香港銀行業影響有限，但反映出我們必須確保銀行建立穩健架構，即使發生嚴重的情況仍能維持關鍵業務運作。令人鼓舞的是，目前香港所有銀行均建立了運作穩健性架構，並已經進入配對工作及情景測試的重要階段，通過識別和修補脆弱環節，確保關鍵業務的運作。

與此同時，為應對多變的網絡威脅，金管局去年着力加強銀行體系的網絡防衛能力，包括發布新指引、開展專題審查。我們並與本地其他金融監管機構合作推進跨行業「網絡地圖」項目，評估和應對金融機構、金融市場基礎設施及科技服務供應商相互連繫可能引發的系統性網絡風險。在2024年完成試行後，該項目將於今年全面展開。

科技發展帶來的另一個重大挑戰是金融詐騙威脅不斷升級且手法日趨複雜，需要銀行、監管機構、執法機構和公眾聯手應對。我們已經要求銀行進一步加強網上銀行保安措施和監察系統。反訛騙及洗黑錢情報工作組（情報工作組）去年亦將覆蓋範圍擴大至所有主要零售銀行及六家儲值支付工具持牌機構，顯著提升了情報交換的效率和規模，沒收的犯罪得益亦隨之增加。同時，促進銀行間訊息分享的法例修訂諮詢獲得廣泛支持，該法例將有助進一步提升銀行偵測及防止金融罪案的能力。

除上述措施外，提升公眾對可疑交易的警覺性及自我保護意識亦同樣重要。2024年，我們擴大了「可疑帳號警示」機制的覆蓋範圍，並推出《保障消費者防詐騙約章2.0》，引入更多參與機構，以擴大約章的保護網，進一步保障公眾。同時，我們亦推出「智安存服務，讓銀行存戶可選擇將部分存款分隔，提供額外保障。

除上述各項協助客戶防範詐騙的措施外，我們亦針對個別客戶可能因衝動而過度借貸，在去年要求零售銀行為無抵押消費信貸產品提供至少七天的冷靜期，讓客戶在訂立貸款協議後能再三仔細考量和評估其財務責任和償還能力。同時，「信資通」個人資料基建項目亦於去年成功推出，在提升個人信貸資料服務方面取得重要進展。

除監管工作外，2024年我們的另一工作重點是確保信貸供應以支持實體經濟，這對作為香港經濟重要支柱的中小企尤為重要。去年，我們與銀行業聯合推出「9+5」支持措施，協助中小企獲取銀行融資應對周轉需要，並助力其升級轉型。銀行已經作出承諾：不會要求按時供款的按揭客戶提前還款，亦不會純粹基於抵押品價值下跌而下調信貸額度。截至目前，已經有超過39,000家中小企獲得信貸支援及新批貸款，涉及信貸額度合共950億港元。銀行亦在貸款組合中預留約3,900億港元專項資金，支持中小企在市場環境變化中持續發展。此外，金管局與香港銀行公會聯合成立「中小企融資專責小組」，從具體個案及行業整體層面為中小企提供支援。鑑於當前貿易爭端及外圍經濟前景不明朗，我們於2025年4月再新增三項針對特定行業的支持措施，進一步加強對多個行業中小企的支持。與此同時，我們還推出了兩項措施以支持香港整體經濟發展。

在維護銀行體系穩定和提升其運作效率方面，我們持續推動銀行業的科技應用，並着力加快銀行業採用金融科技的步伐。目前，香港所有零售銀行均已經將金融科技應用於日常營運。此外，鑑於生成式人工智能(GenAI)在強化銀行業風險管理、防範詐騙和提升客戶體驗方面的潛力，金管局與數碼港去年合作推出「GenAI沙盒」，鼓勵銀行在負責任的前提下應用GenAI。我們同時向銀行發布指引，明確規定銀行若在面向客戶的服務中應用GenAI ，必須確保客戶獲得充分保障。此外，金管局內部亦積極運用GenAI技術，提升分析和監管效率。除GenAI外，我們還通過推出全新FiNETech系列活動、建立配對平台「FintechConnect」，以及舉辦一系列跨行業交流活動，促進金融服務與科技界的連繫，推動金融科技生態圈的合作與創新發展。

# 鞏固香港國際金融中心的地位

儘管2024年充滿挑戰和不確定性，香港仍穩守國際金融中心的領先地位，更在多個領域和國際影響力方面持續拓展提升。

香港作為連接中國內地與國際市場的重要橋樑，扮演着無可比擬的獨特角色。通過推出各項有利措施和加強與各方協作，香港不斷鞏固提升其作為區內金融科技與可持續金融樞紐的地位。有關我們在綠色和可持續金融方面的具體工作，可參閱《二零二四年可持續發展報告》。

# 人民幣業務增長迅速，深化與內地金融合作

2024年，香港人民幣業務持續保持良好勢頭，在貿易結算支付、離岸債券發行，尤其是離岸銀行貸款方面均錄得顯著增長。人民幣即時支付結算系統創下日均交易額的歷史新高，達3.1萬億元人民幣，反映香港全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的作用更為突出。

與此同時，我們持續深化香港與內地的金融互聯互通。2024年推出的「三聯通、三便利」政策，加上今年初公布的六項新措施，均取得重大政策突破。其中，金管局推出1,000億元人民幣貿易融資流動資金安排，為銀行提供穩定且具成本效益的資金來源，以擴展人民幣貿易融資服務，從而支持實體經濟發展。另一項政策突破是允許投資者使用債券通「北向通」持有的在岸債券，特別是國家財政部和政策性銀行發行的在岸債券，作為金管局人民幣流動資金安排、香港場外結算公司及離岸人民幣債券回購業務的合資格抵押品。這一創新舉措提升了在岸債券對離岸投資者的吸引力，有助於促進全球投資者更大程度地參與在岸債券市場。我們去年亦推出「跨境理財通2.0」，實現了多方面的升級優化，包括提供更多元化的投資產品、更靈活的銷售與推廣安排，並擴大個人投資額度。這些措施不僅鞏固了香港作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位，也進一步強化了我們作為連接內地與國際市場的重要門戶角色。

# Stay vigilant and respond to the challenges.

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority rose to the challenge amid a complex external environment. Throughout the year, regional military conflicts continued, and many countries held important elections, while the global economic outlook remained unclear, causing continued volatility in the situation (trade tensions). However, policymakers around the world sought an appropriate balance between controlling rising inflation and supporting economic development, driving robust growth in major economies. Furthermore, with the US launching its first interest rate cut in four years, together with a series of economic support policies implemented in Mainland, market sentiment turned optimistic. Overall, the global macroeconomic environment remains challenging.

Faced with a complex situation, our strategy is to continue to fully unlock Hong Kong’s role as an offshore renminbi business hub, as well as the unique advantages of fintech and green and sustainable finance, to continuously consolidate Hong Kong’s leading position as an International Financial Centre. In 2024, the HKMA made significant progress in these key areas. A number of activities and the Annual International Financial Leaders’ Investment Summit generated strong responses, fully demonstrating the international community’s unwavering confidence in the prospects for Hong Kong’s Financial Centre development.

Facing the cyclical adjustment and structural transformation of Hong Kong’s economy, we have been working closely with the banking sector to support SMEs, alleviate the repayment burden on enterprises in an environment of high interest rates, and at the same time drive their continued development. Together with a number of policy measures launched by the Central and Hong Kong SAR Government, Hong Kong’s economy has achieved a stable recovery. In 2024, Hong Kong’s economy recorded 2.5% moderate growth.

Stepping further into 2025, the global economy continues to face many uncertainties under a more complex geopolitical situation. The increase in trade protection and tariff barriers will lead to disruptions in global supply chains, exacerbate geopolitical economic fragmentation, and add more variables to the prospects for the global economy. Should geopolitical tensions heat up further, it could deliver a double blow to the real economy and global financial markets.

Faced with a complex and challenging economic and financial environment, the HKMA will remain vigilant and earnestly fulfill our responsibilities, striving to maintain the stability of Hong Kong’s currency and banking sector, and to continue to consolidate Hong Kong’s financial centre status. We will deepen our linkages with market participants, actively promote the development of emerging areas, and ensure that Hong Kong maintains a leading edge in the global financial landscape.

# Linked exchange rate system: resilient cornerstone

Linked Exchange Rate System (LERS) has been implemented for over the years, and has consistently been a cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability, successfully withstanding various economic and interest rate cycle challenges, demonstrating strong resilience.

Despite the uncertainty surrounding US interest rate policies in 2024, the Hong Kong dollar currency market continued to operate smoothly according to the linked exchange rate system’s mechanism. Throughout the year, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate fluctuated within the range of 7.75 to 7.85 Hong Kong dollars to 1 US dollar, softening slightly in the first four months of the year due to moderating liquidity, before gradually strengthened, approaching the strong-side exchange rate guarantee level at the end of the year. The stable exchange rate reflects market confidence in the linked exchange rate system. At the same time, the linked exchange rate system continues to receive a high degree of authorization from the International Monetary Fund and the international financial community.

Confidence in the Linked Exchange Rate System in the Market is built on our continued proactive explanation to the Public of the operational mechanisms and advantages of the Linked Exchange Rate System, as well as rigorous market monitoring work. By collecting detailed data, combined with advanced data analysis and Artificial Intelligence technologies, we conduct more timely and comprehensive monitoring of the Market and financial stability assessment.

# The banking sector: remaining resilient in the face of multiple challenges.

In 2024, the Hong Kong banking sector demonstrated strong resilience under multiple macro challenges, with capital and liquidity remaining robust. At the end of 2024, the consolidated capital adequacy ratio of local banks reached 21.8%, higher than the international minimum requirement of 8%. Liquidity was also sufficiently robust, with the liquidity coverage ratio of large banks reaching 178.4% in the fourth quarter, above the statutory minimum threshold of 100%. Affected by persistently high policy rates, unresolved debt issues of some Mainland real estate enterprises, and the soft local commercial real estate market, the ratio of classified loans rose to 1.96% at the end of the year. Due to banks’ prudent credit risk management and maintaining sufficient allocated provisions, related risks are generally manageable.

While continuously monitoring bank credit risks including risks related to residential property mortgage lending, the HKMA, in response to changing property market conditions and risks related to the banking sector, implemented two rounds of adjustments to the countercyclical macroprudential regulation of residential property mortgage loans in 2024. Specifically, the maximum loan-to-value ratio and debt-to-income ratio for all residential properties have returned to the levels before the implementation of countercyclical macroprudential measures in 2009.

While continuously reinforcing banking credit risk management, we also strive to enhance the resilience of banking operations and technology to address the new challenges brought about by increasing reliance on third-party service providers. Taking the CrowdStrike global incident in July of last year as an example, the incident highlighted that operational failures can cause a chain of serious consequences in today’s highly interconnected global environment. Although the incident had a limited impact on the Hong Kong banking sector, it reflects the need for us to ensure that banks have developed robust frameworks that can maintain critical business operations even when severe incidents occur. Encouragingly, all banks in Hong Kong have now developed operational resilience frameworks and have already entered an important phase of mapping and scenario testing, ensuring the operation of critical businesses by identifying and addressing vulnerable sessions.

At the same time, to respond to evolving cyber threats, the HKMA focused last year on strengthening the resilience of the banking sector’s cyber defences, including publishing new guidelines and conducting thematic reviews. We and collaborate with other local financial regulatory agencies to advance the cross-sectoral “Cyber Mapping” project, to assess and deal with systemic cyber risks that may arise from the interconnectedness of financial institutions, financial market infrastructure and technology service providers. Following completion of the pilot run in 2024, the project will be fully launched this year.

Another significant challenge brought about by technological development is the constantly upgrading threats of financial scams and their increasingly complex methods, requiring banks, regulatory agencies, law enforcement, and the public to work together to combat them. We have already asked banks to further enhance their online banking security measures and monitoring systems. The Anti-Money Laundering and fraud intelligence working group (the intelligence working group) also expanded its coverage last year to include all major retail banks and six licensed Stored Value Facility operators, significantly enhancing the efficiency and scale of intelligence sharing, with confiscated proceeds also increasing as a result. At the same time, the consultation on legislative changes to promote information sharing between banks received widespread support, and this legislation will help further enhance banks’ ability to detect and prevent financial crimes.

In addition to the above measures, enhancing public alertness to suspicious transactions and self-protection awareness is also equally important. In 2024, we expanded the coverage of the “Alert for Suspicious Account” mechanism and launched the “Consumer Protection Charter 2.0,” introducing more participating institutions to broaden the Charter’s protection network and further protect the public. At the same time, we also launched “Smart Deposit services, allowing bank depositors to choose to segregate a portion of their deposits, providing additional protection.

In addition to the various measures to assist customers in preventing scams, we also required retail banks last year to provide at least a seven-day cooling-off period for unsecured consumer credit products, to allow customers to carefully assess and evaluate their financial responsibility and repayment ability after entering into a loan agreement. Meanwhile, the “Credit Information Share” infrastructure project was also successfully launched last year, achieving significant progress in enhancing personal credit data services.

In addition to our supervisory work, another key work priority for 2024 is to ensure credit supply to support the real economy, which is particularly important for SMEs as a pillar of the Hong Kong economy. Last year, we jointly launched the “9+5” support initiatives with the banking sector to assist SMEs in obtaining bank financing to meet their working capital needs and to help with their upgrade and transformation. Banks have committed not to require mortgage customers who are making timely repayments to make early repayments, nor will they lower credit limits solely based on a decline in collateral value. As of now, more than 39,000 SMEs have received credit support and new loan approvals, involving a total credit amount of HK$95 billion. Banks have also reserved approximately HK$390 billion in dedicated funds within their loan portfolios to support SMEs’ continued development in a changing market environment. Furthermore, the HKMA and the Hong Kong Association of Banks jointly established a Taskforce on SME Financing to provide support to SMEs from both individual cases and an industry-wide level. Given the current trade disputes and uncertain external economic prospects, we added three sector-specific support initiatives in April 2025 to further strengthen support for SMEs in various industries. At the same time, we have also launched two initiatives to support the overall economic development of Hong Kong.

In maintaining the stability of the banking sector and enhancing its operational efficiency, we continue to promote the applications of technology in the banking sector and are committed to accelerating the adoption of financial technology by banks. Currently, all retail banks in Hong Kong have already applied financial technology to their day-to-day operations. Furthermore, given the potential of Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) in strengthening banking sector risk management, preventing scams and fraud, and enhancing customer experience, the HKMA collaborated with Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation last year to launch the “GenAI Sandbox,” encouraging banks to apply GenAI responsibly. We have also issued guidance to banks, clearly requiring that if they apply GenAI in customer-facing services, they must ensure adequate protection for customers. In addition, the HKMA is also actively using GenAI technology internally to enhance analysis and supervisory efficiency. Besides GenAI, we are also promoting engagement between the financial services and technology sectors through the launch of the new FiNETech series of events, the establishment of the matchmaking platform “FintechConnect,” and the organisation of a range of cross-sectoral exchange activities, to foster collaboration and innovative development within the financial technology ecosystem.

# Consolidating Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre.

Despite the challenging 2024 and uncertainties, Hong Kong remains a leading international financial centre, and continues to expand and enhance its position in various areas and its international influence.

Hong Kong plays a unique role as an indispensable bridge connecting Mainland China and international markets. By launched various favorable measures and strengthening cooperation with all parties, Hong Kong continuously consolidates and enhance its position as a regional hub for fintech and sustainable finance. For details on our work in green and sustainable finance, see the “2024 Sustainable Development Report.”

# RMB business grew rapidly, deepening cooperation with Mainland financial entities.

In 2024, Hong Kong’s renminbi business continued to maintain robust growth momentum in trade settlement payments, offshore bond issuance, and particularly offshore bank lending. The Real-Time Gross Settlement system for renminbi payments recorded a new high in daily transaction volume, reaching 3.1 billion renminbi, reflecting the increasingly prominent role of Hong Kong as a hub for offshore renminbi business.

Meanwhile, we continue to deepen financial connectivity between Hong Kong and the Mainland. The “Three Connect, Three Facilitate” policies launched in 2024, together with the six new initiatives announced earlier this year, have all achieved significant policy breakthroughs. Among these, the HKMA launched a RMB 100 billion trade finance liquidity facility to provide banks with a stable and cost-effective source of funds to expand trade finance services in RMB, thereby supporting the development of the real economy. Another policy breakthrough is allowing investors to use onshore bonds held through the Northbound Bond Connect as eligible collateral for the HKMA’s RMB liquidity facility, Hong Kong’s offshore clearing houses, and offshore RMB bond repurchase business, particularly onshore bonds issued by the Ministry of Finance and policy banks. This innovative move enhances the attractiveness of onshore bonds to offshore investors and helps promote greater participation by global investors in the onshore bond market. We also launched “Wealth Management Connect 2.0” last year, which realized multifaceted upgrades and enhancements, including providing a more diversified range of investment products, more flexible sales and promotion arrangements, and expanding individual investment quotas. These measures not only consolidate Hong Kong’s status as a global hub for offshore renminbi business but also further strengthen our role as an important gateway connecting the Mainland and international markets.

# 2024 年摘要

# 經濟及金融環境

香港經濟在2024年錄得溫和增長，主要受惠於貨物出口在外部需求改善及全球科技周期復甦下有所反彈。勞工市場保持穩健，通脹在外圍價格壓力進一步減退下維持溫和。本港股市顯著回升，而物業市場則因市場氣氛在持續高息環境下受壓而大致疲弱。鑑於貿易緊張局勢不斷升級，預計2025年香港經濟將會面對充滿挑戰的外圍環境。然而，中國內地積極推出經濟刺激措施， 加上為本地企業提供的多方面支持，應能鞏固營商信心。香港亦會繼續加強國際交往合作，以及深化區域合作。

香港銀行體系維持穩健，資本及流動性均十分充裕，整體資產質素維持可控。

# 貨幣穩定

儘管美國貨幣政策走向、環球增長前景及地緣政治局勢存在不明朗因素，港元外匯及貨幣市場繼續保持暢順有序。港元匯率在2024年首4個月回軟，然後在年內其餘時間轉強。作為香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石，聯繫匯率制度一直展現強大抵禦外來衝擊的能力。

# 銀行體系穩定

金管局迅速採取措施支援本地中小型企業，並透過風險為本監管與應變規劃保障銀行體系穩定，另又提供監管指引及支持業界應對新生風險，以提升銀行業的運作穩健性與網絡防衛韌性。為鼓勵應用金融科技，金管局推出連串跨行業項目，包括「生成式人工智能沙盒」。

金管局推出《保障消費者防詐騙約章2.0》、「智安存」，以及有關銀行無抵押消費信貸產品的冷靜期，以加強銀行消費者保障。此外，金管局向銀行提供有關在面向客戶的服務中應用生成式人工智能的指引，又就二手物業買賣交易提供多一種支付安排與業界緊密合作。金管局亦發出數碼資產相關活動指引、優化「跨境理財通」業務試點及放寬多項對數字銀行的限制，並完成個人信貸資料服務全面過渡至「信資通」。

金管局在香港的打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集制度方面扮演重要角色。透過加強公私營夥伴合作平台的情報交換和合作，可疑交易報告的數量顯著增加，因而能更有效沒收犯罪得益。有關促進銀行分享訊息的法例修訂的諮詢得到廣泛支持，並將進一步協助偵測及防止金融罪行。此外，金管局就應用人工智能監察可疑活動以及防範及制止授權支付詐騙向銀行發出指引，並優化「可疑帳號警示」機制。

金管局在香港實施包括資本充足及披露等國際監管標準方面取得良好進展。此外，香港存款保障計劃的多個範疇均作出優化，以加強對存款人的保障。

金管局繼續推進確保處置機制具公信力的工作，實施處置標準，規定銀行須更新與對手方的金融合約，減低處置中的失序地提前終止風險。此外，金管局在制定銀行的首選處置策略、應對處置可行性障礙，以及提升處置執行能力方面均取得顯著進展。

# 香港的國際金融中心地位

金管局與內地及香港有關當局合作，推出一系列措施，共同深化及擴展香港與內地金融市場的互聯互通，包括優化「跨境理財通」；擴大金管局人民幣流動資金安排及「北向互換通」交易的合資格抵押品範圍；以及優化「北向互換通」。這些措施有助強化香港的門戶角色，並鞏固其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位。

金管局在鞏固香港金融平台的競爭力方面亦取得良好進展，涵蓋債券發行、資產及財富管理、綠色和可持續金融，以及企業財資中心等範疇。為宣傳香港的金融服務，金管局加強向海外及內地持份者的市場推廣工作，讓大家充分認識香港金融體系的穩健及其帶來的機遇。第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」及多項其他盛事成功舉辦，不僅有助提升香港作為主要國際金融中心的形象，更製造正面的漣漪效應。此外，金管局積極參與多個國際及區內的央行及監管組織，繼續對維持金融穩定及促進金融市場發展的全球工作作出貢獻。

金管局在「金融科技2025」策略的各個範疇均取得顯著進展，包括央行數碼貨幣及數據基建。另一方面，金管局正與中國人民銀行緊密合作，推動落實香港「轉數快」與內地網上支付跨行清算系統互聯，實現跨境支付。

# 儲備管理

2024年環球金融市場表現大致良好，主要經濟體錄得穩定增長，主要央行亦隨着通脹逐步放緩而陸續下調政策利率。在此背景下，外匯基金錄得2,188億港元的投資收入，投資回報率為5.2%。

金管局繼續致力推動資產多元化及負責任投資。與此同時，長期增長組合自2009年開展投資以來的年率化內部回報率為11.2%。

# 機構職能

金管局透過不同渠道與社會及市場保持密切聯繫，提升公眾對金管局政策及工作的了解。

對內方面，金管局致力建立一支靈活應變及專業的工作團隊，同時遵守嚴格的財政紀律及提升數碼能力，應對變化及確保有效執行各項政策及措施。

# 2024 Highlights

# Economic and financial environment

Hong Kong’s economy recorded moderate growth in 2024, mainly driven by a rebound in merchandise exports as external demand improved and the global technology cycle recovered. The labor market remained resilient, and inflation stayed moderate as external price pressures further eased. The Hong Kong stock market rebounded significantly, while the property market remained largely soft due to market sentiment being pressured by continued high interest rates. Given the escalating international trade tensions, Hong Kong’s economy is expected to face a challenging external environment in 2025. However, mainland China’s proactive launch of economic stimulus measures, together with the multifaceted support provided to local enterprises, are expected to consolidate business confidence. Hong Kong will continue to strengthen international collaboration and deepen regional cooperation.

Hong Kong’s banking sector remains resilient, with capital and liquidity both robust, and the overall asset quality remains manageable.

# Currency stability

Despite uncertainties surrounding the direction of the US monetary policy, global growth prospects and geopolitical tensions, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange and monetary market continued to operate smoothly and efficiently. The Hong Kong dollar exchange rate softened in the first four months of 2024, and then strengthened for the rest of the year. As a cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability, the linked exchange rate system has consistently demonstrated strong resilience in withstanding external shocks.

# Banking sector stability

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority swiftly launched measures to support local small and medium-sized enterprises, and through risk-based regulation and contingency planning provided protection for the stability of the banking sector. It also provides regulatory guidance and support to the industry to respond to new risks, in order to enhance the soundness of operations and cyber resilience of the banking sector. To encourage the application of financial technology, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority launched a series of cross-sectoral projects, including the “Generative Artificial Intelligence Sandbox”.

The HKMA launched the “Protection of Consumers Charter 2.0” against scams, “Smart Deposit”, and a cooling-off period for unsecured consumer credit products to enhance consumer protection for banking customers. In addition, the HKMA provides guidance to banks on applying Generative Artificial Intelligence in customer-facing services, and is working closely with the industry to provide one more Payment arrangement for secondary property transactions. The HKMA also issued guidelines related to Digital asset activities, enhanced the Pilot Scheme for Wealth Management Connect business, relaxed a number of restrictions on Digital banks, and completed the full transition of personal consumer credit reference services to “CreditGo”.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority plays an important role in Hong Kong’s Anti-Money Laundering and counter-terrorism financing regime. Through enhanced intelligence sharing and co-operation via public-private partnership platforms, the volume of suspicious transaction reports has increased significantly, thereby enabling more effective confiscation of proceeds of crime. Consultation on legislative changes to promote banks sharing information received widespread Support, and increases further assistance in detecting and preventing financial crime. Furthermore, the HKMA issues guidance to banks on applying Artificial Intelligence to monitor suspicious activity and prevent and disrupt authorised Payment scams and fraud, and enhances the “suspicious Account alerts” mechanism.

The HKMA has made good progress in implementing International regulatory standards, including capital adequacy and disclosure. In addition, various areas of the Hong Kong Deposit Protection Scheme have been enhanced to strengthen protection for depositors.

The HKMA continues to push forward with work to enhance the credibility of the resolution mechanism, implement resolution standards, require banks to update financial contracts with counterparties, and reduce the risk of disorderly early termination during resolution. In addition, the HKMA has made significant progress in determining banks’ preferred resolution strategies, dealing with barriers to resolvability, and enhancing the capacity for resolution execution.

# Hong Kong’s international financial centre status

The HKMA, together with related authorities in the Mainland and Hong Kong, has launched a range of measures to jointly deepen and expand connectivity between Hong Kong and the Mainland’s Financial markets, including enhancements to “Wealth Management Connect”; expanding the scope of eligible collateral for the HKMA’s RMB Liquidity and Northbound Bond Connect transactions; and optimising “Northbound Bond Connect”. These measures help reinforce Hong Kong’s gateway role and underpin its status as a global hub for offshore renminbi business.

The HKMA has also made good progress in consolidating Hong Kong’s financial centre’s competitiveness, covering areas such as bond issuance, asset and wealth management, green and sustainable finance, and corporate treasury centres. To promote Hong Kong’s financial services, the HKMA has strengthened its market outreach to overseas and the Mainland stakeholders, ensuring they have a full understanding of the soundness of Hong Kong’s financial system and the opportunities it brings. The third ‘Investment Summit’ and various other major events were successfully held, not only helping to enhance Hong Kong’s image as a leading international financial centre, but also creating a positive ripple effect. In addition, the HKMA actively participates in various international and regional central banks and regulatory organisations, continuing to contribute to the global work of maintaining financial stability and promoting financial market development.

The HKMA has made significant progress in all areas of the “Fintech 2025” strategy, including central bank digital currency and data infrastructure. On the other hand, the HKMA is currently working closely with the People’s Bank of China to promote the implementation of the linkage between the Hong Kong “Faster Payment System” and the Mainland’s cross-border bank-to-bank clearing system for online payments, achieving cross-border Payment.

# Reserves Management

In 2024, global Financial markets performed generally well, with major economies recording stable growth, and major central banks also gradually lowered policy rates as inflation softened. Against this Background, the Exchange Fund recorded investment income of HK$218.8 billion, with a rate of return of 5.2%.

The HKMA continues its efforts to promote asset diversification and responsible investment. Meanwhile, the long-term growth portfolio has achieved an annualised internal rate of return of 11.2% since its inception in 2009.

# Corporate functions

The HKMA maintains close linkages with the public and markets through various channels, enhancing public understanding of the HKMA’s policies and work.

Internally, the HKMA strives to establish a agile contingency and professional workforce, while maintaining strict financial discipline and enhancing digital capabilities, to respond to changing circumstances and ensure effective execution of various policies and measures.

金管局、香港數碼港管理有限公司（數碼港）及香港金融科技協會共同主辦第二屆FiNETech，吸引來自銀行、證券、保險及科技領域的超過300名專業人士參加。

活動期間，金管局與數碼港宣布推出新的生成式人工智能(GenAI)沙盒，旨在促進銀行業負責任地創新發展GenAI。首批GenAI沙盒參與者名單於12月公布，包含來自十家銀行和四家技術合作夥伴的15個用例。

# 8月15日

金管局聯同警方、銀行公會及香港中資銀行業協會宣布一系列保護大學生的措施，以免其成為騙案的受害人。

# 8月18日

金管局與馬爾代夫Maldives Monetary Authority簽署諒解備忘錄，加強監管信息的交流及合作。

# 8月19日

金管局向銀行發出指引，就應用GenAI提供一套指導原則以保障消費者。金管局亦鼓勵銀行積極探索利用人工智能加強消費者保障。

# 8月23日

金管局與銀行公會共同成立聯合「中小企融資專責小組」，從個案及行業層面進一步推動支持中小企的工作。

# 9月9日

金管局發出通告分享人工智能在監察可疑活動方面帶來的優勢，以及當局為支持和加快銀行應用人工智能所採取的措施，包括在11月與數碼港合辦論壇，分享相關經驗。

# 9月26日

金管局與證券及期貨事務監察委員會（證監會）聯合發表就優化香港場外衍生工具匯報制度聯合諮詢總結文件。建議的優化措施將於2025年9月29日生效。

# 9月27日

金管局發表《金融服務領域的生成式人工智能研究報告》，深入探討GenAI的變革潛力，及其對金融業的影響，特別是在營運效率、風險管理和客戶參與方面。

# 9月30日

金管局發表有關認可機構為協助防範或偵測罪案而交換訊息的公眾諮詢總結。回應者普遍支持建議。

# 10月9日

金管局及銀行公會支持由廉政公署推出的《銀行業誠信約章》，並聯同廉政公署合辦《誠信約章》啟動禮。30間銀行的管理層出席啟動禮，涵蓋香港主要零售銀行和私人財富管理銀行。

# 10月10日

《2024年〈2023年銀行業（資本）（修訂）規則〉（生效日期）公告》刊憲，指定2025年1月1日為《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案在香港生效的日期。

# 10月10日

為防範支付卡交易的惡意程式騙案，金管局向銀行提供指引，進一步加強網上支付卡交易的保安。自2024年底起，銀行客戶可透過流動銀行應用程式而非一次性手機短訊認證網上支付卡交易。

# 10月16日

金管局向銀行發出指引，調整適用於物業按揭貸款的逆周期宏觀審慎監管措施。經修訂後，所有住宅物業和非住宅物業的按揭成數上限劃一為七成，「供款與入息比率」上限劃一為五成。

# 10月16日

政府宣布推出「中小企融資擔保計劃」優化措施，容許借款企業就現有及新造貸款申請最多12個月「還息不還本」。另外，八成和九成信貸擔保產品的最長貸款擔保期分別延長至十年和八年，並向兩種擔保產品下的新造貸款提供「部分本金還款」選項。這些措施於11月18日生效。

# 10月18日

金管局聯同銀行業推出五項新措施，從資金及銀行產品和服務方面，進一步支持中小企持續發展，並協助它們開拓新的業務與市場。其中包括釋放銀行資本便利中小企融資需求；預留專項資金支持中小企，以及推出更多協助中小企轉型的信貸產品及服務。

# 10月28日

金管局推出跨行業金融科技配對平台「Fintech Connect」，旨在連繫金融機構與金融科技服務商。平台一站式協助準確配對金融科技服務的供求，促進合作和創新。金管局與深圳市前海深港現代服務業合作區管理局合作，納入前海的金融科技服務商，進一步強化平台，提升粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）的合作，推動金融科技生態圈的共同成長。

# 11月5日

金管局向經營發行支付卡及收單業務的銀行發出有關支付卡直接付款授權的指引，以加強在商戶暫停營業或結業時對消費者的保障。

# 11月8日

金管局為無抵押消費信貸產品引入冷靜期，以推廣負責任借貸及減低衝動和過度借貸的風險。

# 11月11日

金管局、數碼港、銀行公會和香港中資銀行業協會合辦「中小企數碼科技方案展示日」。超過100位來自餐飲及零售業的中小企、銀行代表，以及科技方案供應商就銀行業如何透過大數據及科技支持中小企數碼轉型交流意見；科技服務公司亦於現場展示各種為中小企而設的數碼科技方案。

# 11月13日

金管局與警方、數字政策辦公室以及銀行公會聯合舉辦反網絡詐騙工作坊，以提升業界對深偽技術詐騙手法的認識，並分享管理相關風險的良好做法。

# 2024 year major events chronology

# Currency stability

# 9 months 16 day

To promote the development of the bond markets in Hong Kong and Macau, the Central Moneymarkets Unit of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Central Securities Depository and Clearing System under the Monetary Authority of Macau have established a direct link.

# Oct 25

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will increase the number of primary liquidity-providing banks in the Hong Kong offshore renminbi market to 11 banks, and increases the total amount of renminbi liquidity that can be provided under the primary liquidity-providing bank arrangements from RMB 180 billion to RMB 200 billion.

# banking sector

# Feb 7

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority releases published the Report on the Digital advancement process of Anti-Money Laundering and Anti-Terrorist funding regulation: Where Now and Outlook, detailing how to strengthen and modernise Anti-Money Laundering regulation.

# Feb 2nd

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority issued two circulars to banks, providing guidance on the sale and distribution of tokenized products and providing digital asset keeping services.

# Feb 28

The HKMA issued guidance to banks to adjust the countercyclical macroprudential regulatory measures applicable to mortgage lending, as well as other related regulatory requirements. The main legislative changes include: (1) increasing the maximum loan-to-value (LTV) ratio for self-occupied residential properties valued at HK$30,000,000 or below to 70%; for self-occupied residential properties valued at HK$35,000,000 or above to 60%; and for non-self-occupied residential properties to 60%; (2) increasing the maximum LTV ratio for non-residential properties to 70%; (3) increasing the maximum LTV ratio for property mortgage loans with approval based on asset level to 60%; and (4) suspending the implementation of the stress testing requirement assuming a 200 basis points increase in interest rates.

# Feb 28

“SME financing Guarantee Scheme”’s “80% credit Guarantee Product” and “90% credit Guarantee Product” application period is extended to March 31, 2026.

# 3 months 28 day

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the “Banking Sector SME Loan Coordination Mechanism”, has launched nine initiatives to support SMEs in obtaining bank financing and assist them in continued development. These include not requiring mortgage customers to make timely repayments to allow for early repayment; adjusting credit amounts to provide customers with at least a six-month transition period; and actively considering providing interest and fee reductions for SMEs in need.

# April 1st

Introduce a 1% meanwhile neutral countercyclical buffers capital.

# Apr 10

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Hong Kong Association of Banks (Banking Association) launched the “Protection of Consumers Charter 2.0” to expand the scope of the Charter and further assist the public in preventing credit card scams and other digital scams. The “2.0” Charter has received full support from various government departments, financial supervisory institutions and related entities; over 230 financial institutions and merchants from different industries are participating.

# Apr 26th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority launched the FiNETech series to promote financial technology applications. The first FiNETech brought together about 100 banks, Securities companies, insurance companies, and technology companies to jointly discover advanced collaboration arrangements in wealth technology, insurance technology, green technology, Artificial Intelligence, and distributed classification technologies.

# May 3

The HKMA published the “Hong Kong Sustainable Finance Taxonomy” to provide industry practitioners with a basis for making informed decisions when developing green and sustainable finance, and to promote the flow of green capital.

# June 21st

The banking sector provides guidelines to banks to strengthen consumer protection and prevent fraudulent telephone calls.

On the same day, the Banks Association launched the newly revised “Code of Conduct for Voluntary Operations of Direct Sales via Telephone to Persons,” providing enhancements to guidelines for the industry regarding telephone sales activities.

# June 24th

The HKMA, the Association of Banks and the Association of Mainland Banks in Hong Kong co-organise the “Banking Sector Support for SMEs Workshop”, bringing together 200 representatives from the banking sector and chambers of commerce, as well as SME operators, to exchange opinions on the support measures and diversified services provided by the banking sector to SMEs.

# June 25

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority shared key work priorities in combating scams at the kick-off ceremony of the “Celebrating the Return to the Motherland • Financial services for SMEs go into the community” special lecture.

# June 28

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority issues two supervisory circulars to authorized institutions, reminding industry practitioners that they should be following all related laws and regulatory requirements when conducting pilot cross-border data transfer.

# July 3rd

The Legislative Council passed the “2024 Deposit Protection Scheme (Amendment) Bill” draft, and will implement enhancements to the various measures of the deposit protection scheme in two phases. The first phase of enhancements will officially take effect on Oct 1, including raising the deposit protection amount per depositor per bank to 800,000 Hong Kong dollars.

# Aug 1

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the Hong Kong Police Force and the banking Association, announced that the coverage of the “suspicious account alerts” mechanism will be expanded to include online banking and teller transfers. The scope of the alert mechanism will further expand in December to include automated teller machine (including cash deposit machine) transactions.

A range of anti-scam measures were also launched simultaneously, for example, the Monetary Authority, police, and banking sector together established a mechanism to provide more timely and updated alerts for fake bank websites and telephone scams via the “Anti-Fraud Vigilance App”.

# Aug 2nd

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority shared insights on measures to prevent and detect financial crime at the “Financial sector Anti-Money Laundering workshop 2024”.

# Aug. 5

The Monetary Authority published a summary of public consultation regarding the review of the three-tier banking system, with respondents broadly supporting the recommendations to implement a new two-tier banking system.

# Aug. 6

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority published a review report on virtual banks. According to the review results, the development of virtual banks have already achieved the three policy goals of introducing virtual banks in Hong Kong.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority subsequently published a summary of public consultation regarding the proposal to rename “virtual banks” to “digital banks” in October. Respondents generally support the proposal. The new name and the relaxations to their business and operations took effect on October 25.

# Aug. 8

Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation (Hong Kong Mortgage Corporation Limited) 1 introduces new arrangements under the mortgage insurance Scheme, considering approval on a case-by-case basis for eligible homeowners renting out their residential properties starting this year.

# Aug. 9

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and Indonesia Financial Services Authority/Otoritas signed a Memorandum of Understanding, strengthening engagement and collaboration in regulatory information.

# Aug 13 day

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Hong Kong Digital Port Management Limited (Digital Port), and the Hong Kong Fintech Association jointly organise the second edition of FiNETech, which attracted more than 300 professional individuals to participate from the banking, Securities, insurance and technology fields.

During the activity period, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and Hong Kong Science and Technology Parks Corporation announced the launch of a new Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) Sandbox, which aims to promote responsible innovation and development of GenAI in the banking sector. The list of initial GenAI Sandbox participants will be announced in December, including 15 use cases from ten banks and four technology collaboration partners.

# Aug 15 day

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the police, the Banks Association, and the Mainland Chinese banking sector Association, announced a range of measures to protect university students from becoming victims of scams.

# Aug. 18

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Maldives Monetary Authority signed a Memorandum of Understanding, strengthening engagement and collaboration on regulatory information.

# Aug 19

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority provides guidelines to banks, offering a set of core principles for applying GenAI to protect consumers. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also encourages banks to actively explore leveraging Artificial Intelligence to strengthen consumer Protection.

# Aug 23

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the banking Association jointly established a “SMEs financing Taskforce”, to further promote and support the work of SMEs from individual cases and industry level(s).

# 9 months 9 day

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority provides a circular sharing the advantages of Artificial Intelligence in monitoring suspicious activity, as well as the measures the authority is taking to support and accelerate the application of Artificial Intelligence in banks, including co-organising a forum with Hong Kong-based Digital Port in November to share related experiences.

# Sep 26th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) jointly published a concluding documents on the consultation regarding enhancements to the reporting system for over-the-counter (OTC) derivatives in Hong Kong. The proposed enhancements will take effect on 29 Sep 2025.

# Sep 27th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority published a Report on Generative Artificial Intelligence Research in the Financial Services sector, delving into the transformative potential of GenAI and its impact on the financial industry, particularly in areas of operational efficiency, risk management, and customer participation.

# 9 months 30 days

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority published a summary of public consultation regarding information exchange among authorized institutions to prevent or detect crime. Respondents generally Support the recommendations.

# Oct 9

The HKMA and the Association of Banks support the Integrity Charter launched by the ICAC, and co-host the Integrity Charter kick-off ceremony together with the ICAC. Management personnel from 30 banks attended the kick-off ceremony, covering major retail banks and private wealth management banks in Hong Kong.

# Oct. 10

“Notice of the Effective Date of the 2024 ‘2023 Banking Sector (Capital) (Amendments) Rules’” has been gazetted, specified Jan 1, 2025 as the date on which the final reform package of “Basel III” takes effect in Hong Kong.

# Oct. 10

To prevent payment card transaction malware scams, the Monetary Authority provides guidance to banks to further strengthen the security of online payment card transactions. From the end of 2024, bank customers can authenticate online payment card transactions through mobile banking applications instead of one-time SMS authentication.

# Oct 16

The HKMA provides guidance to banks to adjust countercyclical macroprudential supervisory measures applicable to mortgage lending. Following amendments, the maximum loan-to-value ratio for all residential properties and non-residential properties is uniformly set at 70%, and the maximum “debt-to-income ratio” is uniformly set at 50%.

# Oct 16

The Government announced the launch of enhancements to the “SME financing Guarantee Scheme”, allowing borrowing enterprises to apply for up to 12 months of “interest-only repayment” on existing and new loans. In addition, the maximum loan guarantee period for 80% and 90% Guarantee Products will be extended to ten years and eight years respectively, and a “partial principal repayment” option will be provided for new loans under the two types of Guarantee Products. These measures will take effect on November 18.

# Oct 18 day

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the banking sector, launched five new initiatives to further support the continued development of SMEs and assist them in capturing new business and markets, from the perspectives of capital and banking products and services. These include relaxing bank capital to facilitate the financing needs of SMEs; setting aside dedicated funds to support SMEs, and launching additional credit products and services to assist SMEs in their transformation.

# Oct 28

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority launched the cross-sectoral financial technology matching platform “Fintech Connect,” which aims to link financial institutions with financial technology service providers. The platform provides one-stop assistance for precise matching of the supply and demand for financial technology services, promote collaboration and innovation. The HKMA is collaborating with the Shenzhen Qianhai Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Modern Service Industry Cooperation Zone Administration to include financial technology service providers from Qianhai, further strengthen the platform, enhance cooperation in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (GBA), and drive the common growth of the financial technology ecosystem.

# November 5th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority provides guidelines on payment card direct payment authorisation to banks operating issuing payment cards and acquiring business, to strengthen protection for consumers when merchants suspend or cease operations.

# November 8th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is introducing a cooling-off period for unsecured consumer credit products to promote responsible borrowing and reduce the risks of impulsive and excessive borrowing.

# November 11th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Digital Hong Kong, the Banks Association, and the Association of Mainland Banks in Hong Kong co-organise the “SMEs Digital Tech Solutions Day”. More than 100 participants from the catering and retail sectors, bank representatives, and tech solution providers exchanged guidance on how the banking sector can support SMEs’ digital transformation through big data and technology; technology service companies also demonstrated a variety of digital tech solutions designed for SMEs on-site.

# November 13th

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the Police Force, the Digital Policy Office and the Banks Association, co-organised a workshop to enhance industry practitioners’ awareness of deepfake technology scams and share practices for managing related risks.

# 2025 年工作重點及前瞻

2025年環球經濟前景仍然不明朗，美國的經濟與貿易政策存在顯著的不確定性，加上美國通脹面對上行風險，以致市場憂慮美國政策利率的未來走向。與此同時，在中國內地公布及陸續推出經濟刺激措施後，內地與香港的市場氣氛改善，而政府推出的各項相關支持措施應可令訪港旅遊業進一步改善。香港金融體系憑藉多年來所建立穩健的抗震能力及充裕的緩衝，有足夠能力抵禦不利衝擊。

金管局將繼續致力促進香港金融體系及基建的穩定與健全。面對不明朗的宏觀經濟環境，我們會保持警惕，力求迅速辨識正浮現的風險，並靈活應對。與此同時，我們會積極把握機遇及創造政策空間，進一步提升香港的國際金融中心地位。我們會繼續謹慎而靈活地管理外匯基金。我們會作出適當的防禦性部署，並維持高流動性，亦會持續多元化投資，致力提高外匯基金的長期投資回報，確保外匯基金能繼續有效維持香港的貨幣及金融穩定。

# 金融體系穩定健全

在新一屆美國政府下，政策走向難以預料，並引致地緣經濟碎片化，因此預期全球經濟不明朗的情況應會在2025年持續。金管局肩負促進香港金融體系穩定健全的重任，將繼續提高警覺，防範各種潛在風險，確保能掌握最新發展，並作好準備隨時為香港經濟提供支援。

# 對潛在風險保持警惕

展望2025年，鑑於宏觀經濟環境不明朗，環球金融市場或會出現波動。然而，香港金融體系憑藉過去多年所建立的抗震能力及緩衝，有足夠能力抵禦不利衝擊。金管局亦有能力、資源及決心維持香港貨幣及金融穩定。

金管局將繼續密切注視本地及外圍環境的風險與不穩定因素，並會按需要採取適當措施維持香港的貨幣及金融體系穩定。我們亦會研究對香港經濟有影響的事項，並評估與這些事項相關的潛在風險。

# 保持銀行體系穩定

宏觀經濟環境的不確定性很可能會對銀行體系帶來挑戰。與此同時，數碼化的持續發展及生成式人工智能(GenAI)等創新科技的應用，既帶來眾多好處，亦不免為銀行增添新的業務操作與科技風險。面對上述環境，金管局將致力於透過提供政策與實務指引，以及與個別銀行以至整體業界的持續監管聯繫與溝通，進一步加強銀行抵禦不同衝擊的能力。同時，我們亦會因應科技發展、客戶預期的變化，以及國際標準與最佳做法，繼續加強及改進銀行規管架構與監管模式。

# 風險為本的監管重點

# 信用、流動性及市場風險

在信貸環境面臨壓力下，金管局將繼續重點監察認可機構的資產質素，並評估它們的信用風險管理手法的成效，特別是涉及貸款分類與撥備，以及問題貸款管理等範疇。同時，我們會與銀行業及商界保持緊密溝通，並鼓勵認可機構在維持審慎信用風險管理的首要原則下，繼續支持實體經濟。

主要先進經濟體利率前景不明朗及地緣政治緊張局勢升溫，致使環球金融市場更趨波動，有見及此，金管局會繼續採取主動，監管認可機構的市場風險管理。因應宏觀經濟環境不明朗，以及銀行服務日益數碼化，我們亦會審視認可機構如何管理流動性風險，以加強它們應付突發性資金流的能力。

# 業務操作及科技風險

金管局會繼續其提升銀行體系整體運作穩健性的工作，審視銀行在識別維持關鍵運作的潛在風險並作出補救方面的進度，以作為其實施運作穩健性架構的其中一部分。

鑑於銀行業日益倚賴第三方服務供應商，金管局會進一步加強銀行對第三方風險的管理，制定新指引以實施巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）所制定的相關國際標準。

在網絡防衛韌性方面，金管局會透過跨界別的「網絡地圖」項目評估系統性網絡風險。該項目正由金管局聯同其他本地金融監管機構按照國際貨幣基金組織的建議共同推進。此外，我們將審視銀行實施「穩固三重數據備份」安排的情況及推出網絡防衛韌性測試框架，以推動銀行加強在遇到嚴峻網絡事故時恢復關鍵運作的能力。

儘管我們留意到銀行業更廣泛採用GenAI等高端技術所帶來的好處，但亦會保持警覺，留意新生風險，並按需要就相關技術的運用提供指引。

我們亦會與業界及其他相關持份者合作，保持機動應對，防患未然，以提升銀行打擊數碼詐騙及防範千變萬化的詐騙手法的能力。

# 打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集

在2025年，金管局將推出制度改革、創新及其他措施，以提升香港打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集生態圈的整體能力、減低來自非法資金流的威脅，以及與最新的國際標準及最佳做法看齊。

作為政府跨部門合作的一部分，我們將協助進行第三次香港洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集風險的全面評估，以加深對科技發展所帶來的潛在弱點的了解，並根據評估結果制定有效且適度的指引，以配合新的穩定幣發行人監管制度的實施。

我們將會繼續在能帶來公眾價值的領域帶領及推廣負責任地應用科技，包括人工智能。相關工作包括加強可疑活動監察，讓銀行能識別及制止更多詐騙及傀儡戶口，從而進一步增加向執法機構提交的優質及有助作出跟進的情報。

為加強打擊詐騙和其他金融罪行的力度，我們將提出所需的法例修訂建議，為銀行間分享個人戶口的訊息創造必要的途徑與保障。為加強偵測非法資金流的速度與數量，金管局將展開有關支付數據分析平台的工作。

# 財富管理及強制性公積金相關業務

在2025年，金管局會就認可機構在證券、投資產品、信託、保險及強制性公積金（強積金）相關業務方面的操守進行現場及非現場審查。我們會重點留意高收益複雜產品、數碼資產及相關投資產品、「跨境理財通」業務、數碼分銷及諮詢平台、長期保險產品及保費融資業務，並會參考市場最新發展及國際標準的修訂。

金管局亦會與其他監管機構及銀行界緊密聯繫，按需要就銷售證券、投資、保險及強積金產品的監管標準提供指引。為促進數碼資產行業可持續及負責任地發展，我們會繼續與政府及其他監管機構合作，確保為數碼資產行業制定穩健、周全和平衡的監管架構。

此外，金管局會促進及監察業界實施「跨境理財通」優化措施的情況，並繼續與業界及相關監管當局聯繫，以進一步優化該計劃及其他銀行相關的跨境項目。

我們亦會按需要整合及釐清有關財富管理及強積金相關業務的現行指引，讓業界更容易掌握金管局的監管規定，便利遵守。

# 制定政策

# 在香港實施巴塞爾標準

《巴塞爾協定三》最終改革方案於2025年1月1日在香港生效。金管局將就最終改革方案在詮釋方面的常見問題持續向認可機構提供指引並加以釐清，以確保業界一致地採納該方案。

巴塞爾委員會在2022年12月發出銀行審慎處理加密資產風險承擔的新標準，再於2024年7月發出具針對性修訂，進一步釐清穩定幣得到優惠監管待遇的準則。同時，巴塞爾委員會亦發表題為「加密資產風險承擔的披露」的文件，列載更新的加密資產風險承擔披露規定。為於香港實施相關標準，金管局會研究可能需要對《銀行業（資本）規則》、《銀行業（披露）規則》、《銀行業（風險承擔限度）規則》（《風險承擔限度規則》）及《銀行業（流動性）規則》等各套規則作出的法例修訂。金管局亦會因應實施經驗及業界回饋，對《風險承擔限度規則》提出若干優化建議。金管局將於2025年上半年就修訂進行法定諮詢，以能按照巴塞爾委員會的時間表，在2026年1月1日實施新標準。金管局亦會制定相關銀行業申報表及輔助指引，以便利認可機構實施新標準。

# 其他監管政策及風險管理指引

為緊貼最新國際標準、監管方法及銀行業的發展，金管局計劃更新多個《監管政策手冊》單元，包括CA-G-5「監管審查程序」、CA-B-2「具系統重要性銀行」、IC-5「壓力測試」、IR-1「銀行帳內的利率風險」及IC-3「認可機構外聘核數師根據《銀行業條例》提交報告書的規定」。《監管政策手冊》單元CR-G-13「對手方信用風險管理」會作出修訂，以反映巴塞爾委員會在2024年12月發出的「對手方信用風險管理指引」提出的穩健做法。

# 巴塞爾委員會的有效監管銀行業的主要原則

巴塞爾委員會於2024年4月發出經修訂的《有效監管銀行業的主要原則》（《主要原則》）。經修訂《主要原則》反映自對上一次在2012年進行修訂以來監管與規管方面的發展，以及最近的結構性趨勢對銀行與銀行體系的影響。金管局將於2025年進行詳盡的自我評估，以確保其監管及規管架構符合經修訂《主要原則》。

# 會計準則

國際會計準則理事會計劃在2025年就動態風險管理(Dynamic Risk Management)發出徵求意見稿。金管局將與其他有關當局合作，就建議的動態風險管理會計模型對現行審慎監管規定的影響作出研究。

# 執法

金管局在2024年就擴大金融管理專員的調查及執法權力的建議諮詢銀行業，以確保他仍具備必要權力有效履行在《銀行業條例》下的職能。經考慮在諮詢中收到的意見後，金管局將調整有關建議，並制定必要的法例修訂，以進一步諮詢各持份者。

# 處置機制

# 2025 work priorities and outlook.

The global economic prospects remain uncertain in 2025, with significant uncertainty surrounding the US’s economic and trade policies, together with upward risk to US inflation, leading to market concerns about the future direction of US policy rates. At the same time, following the announcement and successive launches of economic stimulus measures in Mainland China, market sentiment in the Mainland and Hong Kong has improved, and the various related support measures launched by the Government should be able to further improve the Hong Kong tourism industry. Hong Kong’s financial system, backed by the resilient shock resistance capabilities and robust buffers developed over the years, has adequate ability to withstand adverse shocks.

The HKMA will continue to strive to promote the stability and integrity of Hong Kong’s financial system(s) and infrastructure. Facing an uncertain macroeconomic environment, we will remain vigilant, seeking to quickly identify emerging risks and respond to them with agility. At the same time, we will actively capture opportunities and create policy space to further enhance Hong Kong’s international financial centre status. We will continue to manage the Exchange Fund prudently and with agility. We will implement appropriate defensive deployments and maintain high liquidity, and will also continue to diversify investments, striving to enhance the long-term investment return of the Exchange Fund, ensuring it can continue to effectively maintain Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability.

# Financial system stability and integrity

Under the new US Government, policy direction is difficult to predict and leads to geo-economic fragmentation; therefore, the expectation is that the global economic situation will remain unclear and continue into 2025. The HKMA bears the important responsibility of promoting the stability and integrity of Hong Kong’s financial system(s), will continue to enhance vigilance, prevent various potential risks, ensure it can grasp the latest developments, and prepare to provide support for the Hong Kong economy at any time.

# Be vigilant about potential risks.

Looking ahead to 2025, given the uncertain macroeconomic environment, global financial markets may experience volatility. However, Hong Kong’s financial system, thanks to the resilience and buffers developed over the years, has adequate ability to withstand adverse shocks. The HKMA also has the capabilities, resources and determination to maintain monetary and financial stability in Hong Kong.

The HKMA will continue to closely monitor the risks and instability factors in the local and external environment, and will take appropriate measures as needed to maintain the stability of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial system(s). We will also study issues that affect the Hong Kong economy, and assess potential risks related to these matters.

# Maintain banking sector stability.

The uncertainty in the macroeconomic environment will likely bring challenges to the banking sector. At the same time, the continued development of digitalization and the application of innovative technologies such as Generative Artificial Intelligence (GenAI) bring numerous benefits, but also introduce new business operations and technology risks for banks. Facing the above environment, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will strive to further strengthen the resilience of banks to various shocks by providing policy and practical guidance, as well as continued supervisory engagement and communications with individual banks and the industry as a whole. Simultaneously, we will, following technological developments, changing customer expectations, and international standards and best practices, continue to enhance and improve the banking regulatory framework and supervisory model.

# Risk-based regulatory priority.

# Credit, liquidity, and market risks

Under pressure in the credit environment, the HKMA will continue to closely monitor the asset quality of authorized institutions and assess the effectiveness of their credit risk management approaches, particularly in areas involving loan classification and provisioning, as well as management of problem loans etc. At the same time, we will maintain close communications with the banking sector and business community, and encourage authorized institutions to continue supporting the real economy under the primary principle of maintaining prudent credit risk management.

The unclear prospects for interest rates in major advanced economies and heightened geopolitical tensions have led to increased volatility in global financial markets. In response, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to take the initiative in supervising the market risk management of authorized institutions. Following the uncertain macroeconomic environment, and as banking services become increasingly digital, we will also review how authorized institutions manage liquidity risks, to strengthen their ability to handle sudden capital flows.

# Business tasks and technology risks

The HKMA will continue its work to enhance the overall resilience of the banking sector, reviewing banks’ progress in identifying potential risks to maintaining critical operations and making remedies, as part of its implementation of the operational resilience framework.

Given the increasing reliance of the banking sector on third-party service providers, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will further deepen the management of risks to banks from third parties, and develop new guidance to implement the relevant international standards determined by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (Basel Committee).

In terms of cyber resilience, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will assess systemic cyber risks through the cross-sectoral “Cyber Mapping” project. The project is currently being jointly driven by the HKMA together with other local financial regulatory bodies in accordance with recommendations from the International Monetary Fund. In addition, we will review the implementation by banks of the “robust three-tier data backup” arrangements and launch a cyber resilience testing framework to promote banks’ enhancement of their ability to restore critical operations when facing severe security incidents.

Although we keep itself informed of the benefits brought by the wider adoption of high technologies such as GenAI in the banking sector, we will also remain vigilant, closely monitor new risks, and provide guidance on the use of related technologies as demand.

We will also collaborate with the industry and other related stakeholders, remain agile to respond to challenges, prevent problems before they occur, and enhance banks’ capability to combat digital scams and prevent the ever-changing scam tactics.

# Anti-Money Laundering and countering the Financing of Terrorism.

In 2025, the HKMA will launch regime reforms, innovation and other measures to enhance Hong Kong’s overall resilience in anti-money laundering and countering the financing of terrorism ecosystem, reduce threats from illicit financial flows, and align with the latest international standards and best practices.

As part of the Government’s inter-departmental co-operation, we will assist in conducting the third Hong Kong Anti-Money Laundering and terrorism Financing risks assessment, to enhance understanding of the potential vulnerabilities brought by technological developments, and to formulate effective and proportionate guidance based on the assessment results, in order to adapt to the implementation of new regulatory regime for stablecoin issuers.

We will continue to lead and promote the responsible application of technology, including Artificial Intelligence, in areas that bring value to the Public. Related work includes increasing monitoring of suspicious activities, allowing banks to identify and disrupt more scams and fraudulent Account holders, thereby further increasing the high-quality intelligence submitted to law enforcement agencies, which should be helpful in follow-up investigations.

To strengthen Anti scams and fraud and other financial crime efforts, we will propose the necessary legislative changes recommendations, to create necessary pathways and Protection for banks to share personal Account information. To enhance the speed and volume of detection of illicit funds flows, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will launch related Payment data analysis Platform work.

# Wealth management and related Mandatory Provident Fund business.

In 2025, the HKMA will conduct on-site and non-site due diligence on authorized institutions’ conduct in relation to their Securities, investment products, trusts, insurance and Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) related business. We will closely monitor high return complex products, Digital assets and related products, “Wealth Management Connect” business, digital distribution and consultation platforms, long-term insurance products and premium financing business, and will take into account the latest market developments and amendments to international standards.

The HKMA will also maintain close contact with other regulatory agencies and the banking sector, providing guidance on regulatory standards for the sale of securities, investments, insurance and MPF products as needed. To promote the sustainable development of the digital asset industries, We will continue to collaborate with the Government and other regulatory agencies, ensuring a resilient, comprehensive and balancing regulatory framework is developed for the digital asset industries.

Besides, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will promote and monitor the implementation of enhancements to the Wealth Management Connect measures, and will continue to engage with the industry and related regulatory authority to further optimise the Scheme and other bank-related cross-border projects.

We will also integrate and harmonise existing guidance related to wealth management and Mandatory Provident Fund related business as needed, making it easier for industry practitioners to grasp the HKMA’s regulatory regulation, facilitated maintaining compliance.

# Formulate policies

# Implementing Basel standards in Hong Kong.

The final reform package of “Basel III” will take effect in Hong Kong on Jan 1, 2025. The HKMA will continue to provide guidance to authorized institutions on common questions regarding the interpretation of the final reform package and will harmonise them, to ensure consistent adoption of the solution by the industry.

The Basel Committee issued new standards for banks’ prudential treatment of crypto-asset risks in December 2022, and further issued targeted amendments in July 2024 to further harmonise the criteria for stablecoins to receive preferential regulatory treatment. At the same time, the Basel Committee also published documents titled “Disclosure of Crypto-asset Risk Exposures”, setting out updated disclosure requirements for crypto-asset risk exposures. To implement the relevant standards in Hong Kong, the HKMA will study the legislative changes that may be required to the “Banking (Capital) Rules”, “Banking (Disclosure) Rules”, “Banking (Limits on Exposure) Rules” (“Exposure Limits Rules”) and “Banking (Liquidity) Rules”, etc. The HKMA will also, following implementation experience and industry feedback, propose several enhancement recommendations to the “Exposure Limits Rules”. The HKMA will conduct statutory consultation on the amendments in the first half of 2025, to implement the new standards on 1 January 2026, in accordance with the Basel Committee’s timeline. The HKMA will also develop relevant banking sector reporting forms and supporting guidance to facilitate authorized institutions in implementing the new standards.

# Other supervisory policies and risk management guidelines.

To keep pace with the latest international standards, supervisory methods, and developments in the banking sector, the HKMA plans to update various modules of the Supervisory Policy Manual, including CA-G-5 “Supervisory Review Procedures”, CA-B-2 “Systemically Important Banks”, IC-5 “Stress Testing”, IR-1 “Interest Rate Risk in Banks’ Balance Sheets”, and IC-3 “Requirements for Authorized Institutions’ External Auditors to Submit Reports under the Banking Ordinance”. Module CR-G-13 “Counterparty Credit Risk Management” of the Supervisory Policy Manual will be revised to reflect the robust practices outlined in the “Guidelines for Counterparty Credit Risk Management” issued by the Basel Committee in December 2024.

# Basel Committee’s key principles for the effective supervisory banking sector.

The Basel Committee issued the revised “Core Principles for Effective Banking Supervision” (the “Core Principles”) in April 2024. The revised Core Principles reflect developments in supervision and regulation since the last revision in 2012, as well as the impact of recent structural trends on banks and the banking sector. The HKMA will conduct a detailed self-assessment in 2025 to ensure that its supervisory and regulation framework meets the revised Core Principles.

# Accounting Standards

The International Accounting Standards Board plans to issue a discussion paper on Dynamic Risk Management in 2025. The authority will collaborate with other related authority to study the impact of the proposed dynamic risk management accounting model on existing prudential regulatory regulation.

# Law enforcement.

The Monetary Authority consulted the banking sector in 2024 on recommendations to expand the Monetary Authority’s investigation and enforcement powers, to ensure it still has the necessary powers to effectively perform its functions under the Banking Ordinance. Having considered the feedback received during the consultation, the Monetary Authority will adjust the related recommendations and develop necessary legislative changes, to further consultation with stakeholders.

# Resolution mechanism

# Resolution of policies and standards

Regarding the chapter on practical guidelines for the methods adopted by the HKMA for the resolution of valuation, and the prior capabilities and arrangements that authorized institutions shall have to support timely and prudent resolution valuation – conducting consultation and completing related determining work.
Advances the work of developing policy standards for resolution and restructuring.

# International and cross-border collaboration

Participate in international work regarding policy development and effective implementation of resolution, especially the Financial Stability Board’s efforts through the Resolution Coordination Mechanism Steering Group and various working group initiatives to implement twelve resolution mechanism reform measures planned for 2025.

# 金管局簡介

香港金融管理局是香港的中央銀行機構，主要職能有四項：

- 在聯繫匯率制度的架構內維持貨幣穩定；
- 促進金融體系（包括銀行體系）的穩定與健全；
- 協助鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位，包括維持及發展香港的金融基建；及
- 管理外匯基金。

# 金管局的法定授權

立法會（前稱立法局）於1992年通過《外匯基金條例》修訂條文，授權財政司司長（前稱財政司）委任金融管理專員，金管局隨後在1993年4月1日成立。

金融管理專員的權力、職能及責任由《外匯基金條例》、《銀行業條例》、《金融機構（處置機制）條例》、《存款保障計劃條例》、《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》及其他有關條例明文規定。財政司司長與金融管理專員於2003年6月25日的互換函件，列載彼此在貨幣與金融事務方面的職能與責任的分配，亦披露財政司司長將若干權力轉授予金融管理專員。有關函件為公開文件，可於金管局網站查閱。

外匯基金根據《外匯基金條例》設立，由財政司司長掌有控制權。該條例規定外匯基金須主要運用於影響港元匯價。財政司司長亦可運用外匯基金以保持香港貨幣金融體系的穩定與健全（惟同時須顧及外匯基金的主要目的），藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。

金融管理專員根據《外匯基金條例》委任，以協助財政司司長執行其根據該條例獲授予的職能，以及執行其他條例及財政司司長所指派的職能。金融管理專員的辦公室稱為金管局，金融管理專員即為金管局總裁。

金融管理專員根據《銀行業條例》賦予的職責及權力，規管及監管銀行業務與接受存款業務。根據《銀行業條例》，金融管理專員負責處理香港持牌銀行、有限制牌照銀行及接受存款公司的認可事宜。

《金融機構（處置機制）條例》訂明金融管理專員為銀行界實體的處置機制當局。金融管理專員獲賦予一系列權力，對不可持續經營的銀行界實體進行有秩序處置（有關實體倒閉可能構成系統性風險），以維持金融穩定，同時力求保障公帑。

《證券及期貨條例》及《強制性公積金計劃條例》賦予金融管理專員若干有關銀行證券及強制性公積金業務的權力。

保險業監管局根據《保險業條例》就銀行的保險相關業務向金融管理專員轉授查察及調查權力。

《打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集條例》授權金融管理專員監管銀行遵守該條例下有關客戶盡職審查及備存紀錄的規定。

《存款保障計劃條例》授予金融管理專員責任，就存款保障計劃的運作提供協助，以及啟動從存款保障計劃基金向無力償付的持牌銀行的存款人發放補償。

金融管理專員在《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》的法定架構下，可指定及監察某些重要的結算及交收系統，以及在香港營運的零售支付系統。該條例亦授權金融管理專員管理用作儲存金錢價值並符合該條例指明準則的電子及實物「工具」的發牌制度。

# About the Hong Kong Monetary Authority

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is the central bank institution in Hong Kong, with four main functions:

- Maintaining monetary stability within the Linked Exchange Rate System framework;
- Promote the stability and integrity of the financial system(s), including the banking sector;
- Assist in consolidating Hong Kong’s international Financial Centre status, including maintaining and developing Hong Kong’s infrastructure; and
- Manage the Exchange Fund.

# The HKMA’s statutory authorisation.

The Legislative Council (formerly known as the Legislative Council) passed amendments to the Exchange Fund Ordinance in 1992, authorising the Financial Secretary (formerly known as the Financial Secretary) to appoint the Monetary Authority, and the Monetary Authority was established on April 1, 1993.

The powers, Functions and responsibilities of the Monetary Authority are set out in the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the Banking Ordinance, the Financial Institutions (Resolution Mechanism) Ordinance, the Deposit Protection Scheme Ordinance, the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facility Ordinance and other related Ordinances. The Financial Secretary and the Monetary Authority exchanged letters on June 25, 2003, which set out the division of functions and responsibilities between them in respect of monetary and financial affairs, and also discloses that the Financial Secretary delegated certain powers to the Monetary Authority. The letters are public documents and can be found on the HKMA website.

The Exchange Fund was established under the Ordinance, and is under the control of the Financial Secretary. The Ordinance requires the Exchange Fund to be primarily used to affect the Hong Kong dollar exchange value. The Financial Secretary may also use the Exchange Fund to maintain the stability and integrity of Hong Kong’s monetary financial system(s) (while also considering the primary purpose of the Exchange Fund), with a view to maintaining Hong Kong’s position as an International financial centre.

The Monetary Authority is appointed by the Chief Executive under the Exchange Fund Ordinance to assist the Financial Secretary in the execution of functions conferred on him under the Ordinance, as well as the execution of other Ordinances and functions assigned by the Financial Secretary. The office of the Monetary Authority is known as the HKMA, and the Monetary Authority is the Chief Executive.

The Monetary Authority, vested with the mandate and powers conferred upon it under the Banking Ordinance, regulates and supervises banking business and taking deposits. Under the Banking Ordinance, the Monetary Authority has responsibility for handling authorization matters concerning licensed banks, restricted license banks, and authorized institutions accepting deposits in Hong Kong.

The Financial Institutions (Resolution Mechanism) Ordinance provides that the Monetary Authority is the resolution authority for entities in the banking sector. The Monetary Authority is vested with a range of powers to effect the orderly resolution of unsustainable operating entities in the banking sector (the failure of such entities may pose systemic risk), for maintaining financial stability, while seeking to protect public funds.

The Securities and Futures Ordinance and the Mandatory Provident Fund Schemes Ordinance vested the Monetary Authority with certain powers related to bank securities and Mandatory Provident Fund businesses.

The Insurance Authority, under the Insurance Ordinance, delegates investigation powers relating to the insurance businesses of banks to the Monetary Authority.

The Anti-Money Laundering and Terrorist Financing Ordinance empowers the Monetary Authority to supervise banks to maintain the requirements of the Ordinance related to customer due diligence and record-keeping.

The Deposit Protection Scheme Ordinance confers responsibility on the Monetary Authority to provide assistance with the operations of the Deposit Protection Scheme and to launch payment of compensation from the Exchange Fund Fund to depositors of licensed banks that have failed to meet their obligations.

The Monetary Authority, under the statutory framework of the Ordinance on Payment Systems and Stored Value Payment Instruments, may specify and monitor certain important clearing and settlement systems, as well as retail payment systems operating in Hong Kong. The Ordinance also empowers the Monetary Authority to manage the licensing regime for “tools” used to store monetary value and meet the Standards specified in the Ordinance.

# 機構管治

金管局作為香港的中央銀行機構，深明良好的管治對維持及維護公眾對金管局履行其法定職責的信任及信心的重要性，因此一直致力秉持高水平的機構管治。

為實踐良好機構管治的承諾，金管局：

- 建立了一套清晰的機構管治架構；
- 維持高問責性及透明度，並與各持份者保持緊密聯繫；及
- 實施完善穩健的監控措施以管理風險，並確保所有職級員工的行為及其日常運作均符合指定標準。

金管局的管治架構涵蓋幾個主要部分，包括給予意見和指導的各法定諮詢委員會、問責性與透明度，以及內部監控與外部審計。

# 金管局與特區政府

金管局是中華人民共和國香港特別行政區政府（特區政府）架構的一部分，但可以按與公務員不同的聘用條款聘請員工，以吸引具適當經驗與專門知識的人才。金管局總裁及其員工均為公職人員。金管局的日常運作，在金融管理專員所獲賦予或轉授的法定權力範圍內高度自主。

財政司司長負責釐定香港的貨幣政策目標及貨幣體制：財政司司長於2003年6月25日致金融管理專員的函件中，訂明應透過貨幣發行局制度維持貨幣穩定，將港元匯率保持在約7.80港元兌1美元的水平。金融管理專員須自行負責達成貨幣政策目標，包括決定有關的策略、工具及執行方式，並負責維持香港貨幣制度的穩定與健全。

財政司司長在財經事務及庫務局局長的協助下，負責維持香港金融體系穩定與健全，以及保持香港的國際金融中心地位的政策。為推行這些政策，金融管理專員的職責包括：

- 促進銀行體系的整體穩定與有效運作；
- 與其他有關機構與組織合作，發展債務市場；
- 處理與法定紙幣及硬幣的發行及流通有關的事宜；
- 透過發展支付、結算及交收系統，以及在適當情況下負責操作有關系統，促進金融基建的安全與效率；及
- 與其他有關機構與組織合作，促進對香港貨幣及金融體系的信心，並推行適當的發展市場措施，以協助加強香港金融服務的國際競爭力。

外匯基金由財政司司長掌有控制權。金融管理專員須根據財政司司長轉授的權力，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 諮詢委員會及管理層

# 諮詢委員會

諮詢委員會就金管局主要工作範疇給予意見和指導。

外匯基金諮詢委員會根據《外匯基金條例》成立，就與財政司司長行使對外匯基金的控制權相關的事宜向其提供意見。財政司司長為外匯基金諮詢委員會的當然主席，其他委員（包括金融管理專員）以個人身分，由財政司司長根據香港特別行政區行政長官的授權委任。委員各以本身的專業知識及經驗獲得委任，使外匯基金諮詢委員會廣受裨益。外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下設有五個專責委員會，負責監察金管局特定範疇的工作和給予意見，並透過諮詢委員會向財政政司長報告及提出建議。有關外匯基金諮詢委員會及其轄下五個專責委員會的詳情，請參閱第53至63頁。

銀行業務諮詢委員會及接受存款公司諮詢委員會就有關《銀行業條例》，特別是有關銀行、接受存款公司及有限制牌照銀行經營銀行業務或接受存款業務（視屬何情況而定）的事宜，向香港特別行政區行政長官提供意見。兩個委員會均由財政司司長擔任主席，成員包括金融管理專員及財政司司長根據行政長官的授權而委任的人士。有關銀行業務諮詢委員會及接受存款公司諮詢委員會的詳情，請參閱第64至65頁。

# 管理層

總裁委員會由金管局總裁、副總裁及其他高層人員組成，並由金管局總裁擔任主席。總裁委員會定期開會，向總裁匯報金管局各部門主要工作的進度，並就與金管局運作有關的政策事項向總裁提供意見。有關總裁委員會成員名單，請參閱第66至67頁。

# 問責性與透明度

就日常運作及推行政府政策目標所採用的方法，金管局一直保持高度自主，並同時輔以高問責性及透明度。

金融管理專員由財政司司長委任，因此金管局透過財政司司長向公眾負責；而由於金管局的職權由立法會通過的法律制訂，因此金管局亦透過立法會向公眾負責。金管局亦明白本身肩負更廣泛的責任，促進公眾對金管局角色及目標的認識，並密切留意社會人士所關注的事項。金管局在執行日常工作及與社會保持廣泛聯繫時，堅守盡力提高透明度及保持開放的政策。這項政策有兩大目標：

- 在顧及市場敏感性、商業秘密及機密資料披露的法定限制下，盡量使金融界及公眾充分了解金管局的工作；及
- 確保金管局掌握社會脈搏，並對公眾意見作出適當回應。

# 與公眾溝通

金管局致力促進貨幣與銀行體系穩定，有效管理官方儲備，發展與監察穩健及多元化的金融基建，從而鞏固香港的國際金融中心地位，推動香港經濟發展。

金管局要有效履行職責，便必須取得社會人士的信任。因此，金管局以嚴謹的態度，履行向公眾解釋其政策及工作的責任。金管局與傳媒保持廣泛聯繫，又利用社交媒體平台，以能在數碼時代中更有效與公眾溝通。金管局亦盡力處理備受社會關注而涉及金管局職責範圍的事項，尤其透過傳統及社交媒體適時澄清有關金管局政策的失實資訊及謠言。

此外，金管局辦事處設有資訊中心，分為圖書館及展覽館兩部分，每星期開放六日予公眾參觀及使用。有關金管局與公眾溝通及聯繫的工作，詳見「機構職能一章（第185至191頁）。

# 立法會

金管局與立法會的關係對提高問責性及透明度非常重要。金管局總裁承諾每年三次向立法會財經事務委員會簡報金管局各項工作及政策，並回答有關查詢。金管局總裁定期在財經事務委員會作出的簡報載於金管局網站。

此外，金管局代表不時出席立法會事務委員會及小組委員會會議，闡釋及商討特別事項，以及協助議員審閱條例草案。

# 資訊披露

金管局在透明度方面致力達致國際最高標準，出版各種中英文期刊及專題刊物。金管局的雙語網站(www.hkma.gov.hk)除有專門環節列載經濟研究、統計資料、監管資源、消費者資訊及其他課題外，還載有大量金管局出版的刊物、新聞稿、演講辭及簡報會資料文件。

金管局不時檢討外匯基金及貨幣發行局帳目資料的披露是否足夠。金管局於1999年開始參與國際貨幣基金組織的中央銀行「數據公布特殊標準」計劃。金管局亦公布外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下貨幣發行委員會的會議紀錄，以及貨幣發行局制度運作報告。自1996年起，金管局網站載有銀行業監管政策及指引。

# 內部監控與外部審計

金管局採用穩健有效的監控機制，確保秉持高水平的員工操守、審慎的風險管理，以及適當的制衡。內部及外部審計職能就監控機制是否足夠及具成效提供獨立評估。

# 行為守則

《行為守則》就員工的道德與法律責任提供指引，確保所有職級員工的行為均符合指定標準。

# 內部監控

# 運作監控

作為風險管理的第一度防線，所有部門及分處均有責任識別及評估其工作流程的風險，並制定適當的監控措施，確保金管局日常運作穩妥。

# 機構風險管理

風險管理亦在機構層面進行。由金管局總裁擔任主席的風險委員會，是機構風險管理架構的基石之一。

風險委員會審視和匯報各部門所識別的潛在及新生風險，以及相關監控措施和緩解策略是否充足，並定出適當的跟進行動。

# 內部審計

金管局內部審核處獨立評估不同部門的管治程序、風險管理及監控措施是否足夠及具成效，並提出改善建議。

# 外部審計

根據《外匯基金條例》第7條，外匯基金的財務報表由香港特區政府審計署審核。審計署並無就此項服務收取費用。經審核的外匯基金財務報表刊載於金管局《年報》。
