# Corporate governance

The HKMA, as Hong Kong’s central banking institution, deeply understands the importance of good governance to maintain and uphold Public confidence in the HKMA fulfilling its statutory responsibilities, and therefore continues its efforts to adhere to high standards of corporate governance.

To fulfill the commitment to good corporate governance, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority:

A clear corporate governance framework has been established;
maintaining high accountability and transparency, and operating in co-operation with all stakeholders; and
implementing refined robust controls to manage risk, and ensuring the behaviours of staff at all levels and their day-to-day operations all meet specified standards.

The HKMA’s governance frameworks cover several key parts, including the various statutory Advisory Committees providing advice and guidance, accountability and transparency, and internal controls and external audit.

# The Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the SAR Government

The Monetary Authority is part of the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (the SAR Government) framework, but can hire staff under terms of employment different from those of civil servants, to attract talent with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. The Chief Executive of the Monetary Authority and its staff are all public staff. The day-to-day operations of the Monetary Authority are highly autonomous within the scope of statutory powers vested or delegated to the Monetary Authority.

The Financial Secretary is responsible for determining the monetary policy objectives and monetary structure of Hong Kong. In a letter to the Monetary Authority dated June 25, 2003, the Financial Secretary provides that monetary stability shall be maintained through the monetary issuance system, keeping the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate at around 7.80 Hong Kong dollars to 1 US dollar. The Monetary Authority is responsible on his own for achieving the monetary policy objectives, including determining the related strategies, tools and implementation method, and has responsibility for maintaining the stability and integrity of the Hong Kong monetary system.

The Financial Secretary, with the assistance of the Secretary for Financial Affairs and the Treasury Bureau, has responsibility for maintaining the stability and integrity of Hong Kong’s financial system(s), as well as the policy of preserving Hong Kong’s financial centre status. To implement these policies, the Monetary Authority’s mandate includes:

- Promote the overall stability and effective operations of the banking sector;
- Collaborate with other related institutions and organisations to develop the debt market;
- Handle matters related to the issuance and circulation of statutory banknotes and coins;
- Through developing payment, clearing and settlement systems, and being responsible for operating related systems where appropriate, promote the safety and efficiency of financial infrastructure; and
- Collaborate with other related institutions and organisations to promote confidence in Hong Kong’s currency and financial system, and implement appropriate market development measures to assist in strengthening the international competitiveness of Hong Kong financial services.

The Exchange Fund is under the control of the Financial Secretary. The Monetary Authority shall be responsible to the Financial Secretary for the deployment and investment management of the Exchange Fund, based on powers delegated by the Financial Secretary.

# Advisory Committee and Management levels

# Advisory Committee

The Advisory Committee provides advice and guidance on the HKMA’s main areas of work.

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee was established under the Exchange Fund Ordinance to provide advice to the Financial Secretary on matters related to the exercise of control over the Exchange Fund. The Financial Secretary serves as the ex-officio Chairman of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and other members (including the Monetary Authority) are appointed by the Financial Secretary, with the authorization of the Chief Executive, in a personal capacity. Each member is appointed with their own professional knowledge and experience to benefit the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee. The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has five specialized committees under it, responsible for monitoring the HKMA’s work in specific areas and providing advice, and reporting to and offering recommendations to the Financial Secretary through the Advisory Committee. For details regarding the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee and its five specialized committees, see pages 53 to 63.

The Advisory Committees on banking business and Deposittaking company provide advice to the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region regarding the Banking Ordinance, Special relating to banks, Deposittaking companies and restricted license banks operating banking business or taking deposits (depending on the case). Both committees are chaired by the Financial Secretary, with members including the Monetary Authority and individuals appointed by the Financial Secretary with the authorization of the Chief Executive. For details on the Advisory Committees on banking business and Deposittaking company, See pages 64 to 65.

# Management

The Chief Executive Committee is comprised of the Chief Executive of the HKMA, the Deputy Chief Executive, and other high-level staff, and serves as Chair by the Chief Executive of the HKMA. The Chief Executive Committee will hold regular meetings, report progress on the main work of various departments of the HKMA to the Chief Executive, and provide advice to the Chief Executive on policy issues related to the operations of the HKMA. For the list of Chief Executive Committee members, see pages 66 to 67.

# Accountability and transparency

Regarding the methods adopted for day-to-day operations and implementing government policy objectives, the HKMA has consistently maintained a high degree of autonomy, and is complemented by high accountability and transparency.

The Monetary Authority is appointed by the Financial Secretary, and therefore the Monetary Authority is responsible to the Public through the Financial Secretary; and as the powers of the Monetary Authority are determined by legislation passed by the Legislative Council, the Monetary Authority is also responsible to the Public through the Legislative Council. The Monetary Authority also recognises its own broader responsibilities, promote public understanding of the Monetary Authority’s role and objectives, and closely monitor issues of concern to individuals. In carrying out its day-to-day work and maintaining extensive contacts with the community, the Monetary Authority adheres to efforts to enhance transparency and maintain open policies. This policy has two main objectives:

To the extent permissible under statutory restrictions on the disclosure of market sensitivity, commercial secrecy, and confidential data, enable the financial community and the Public to have a full understanding of the work of the HKMA; and
ensure the HKMA stays in touch with the pulse of society, and make appropriate responses to public opinion.

# Communicate with the Public

The HKMA strives to promote monetary and banking sector stability, effectively manage official Reserves, develop and monitor resilient and diversified financial infrastructure, thereby consolidating Hong Kong’s international Financial Centre status and promote Hong Kong’s economic development.

The HKMA must effectively fulfill its responsibilities to gain the trust of people. Therefore, the HKMA adopts a rigorous approach to fulfill its responsibility to explain its policies and work to the public. The HKMA maintains extensive contacts with the media and leverages social media platforms to communicate more effectively with the public in the Digital age. The HKMA also strives to handle matters of public concern involving the scope of the HKMA’s duties, especially by clarifying inaccurate information and rumors related to the HKMA’s policies through traditional and social media.

In addition, the HKMA office is equipped with an Information Centre, which comprises a library and exhibition area, open to the Public six days a week for visits and use. Related work of the HKMA’s communications and linkage with the Public, See chapter 1 (pages 185 to 191) for more details.

# Legislative Council

The relationship between the HKMA and the Legislative Council is very important for enhancing accountability and transparency. The Chief Executive of the HKMA has committed to providing briefings to the Financial Affairs Committee of the Legislative Council three times a year on the HKMA’s various work and policies, and to answer related questions. Briefing sessions provided by the Chief Executive of the HKMA to the Financial Affairs Committee are published on the HKMA website.

Besides, representatives of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority attend meetings of the Legislative Council Affairs Committee and sub-committee meetings from time to time to explain and discuss particular issues, and to assist Members in reviewing draft legislation.

# Information disclosure

The hkma strives to achieve International highest standards in terms of transparency, published various Chinese and English journals and publications. The hkma’s bilingual website (www.hkma.gov.hk) not only carries a special session set out economic research, statistical data, supervisory resources, consumers information and other topics, but also are included a large number of publications, press releases, speeches and briefing session documents published by the hkma.

The HKMA periodically reviews the adequacy of disclosure of Exchange Fund and Currency Board accounting data. The HKMA began to participate in the International Monetary Fund’s “Special Data Dissemination Standard” for central banks in 1999. The HKMA also publishes the minutes of meetings of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee’s Currency Issuance Committee, as well as reports on the operations of the Currency Board System. Since 1996, the HKMA website has included banking sector regulatory policies and guidance.

# Internal controls and external audit

The HKMA adopts robust and effective control mechanisms, ensuring high standards of staff conduct, prudent risk management, and appropriate checks and balances. Internal and external audit functions provide independent assessment of whether the control mechanisms are adequate and have an impact.

# Code of Conduct

The Code of Conduct provides guidance to staff on ethical and legal responsibilities, ensuring all staff at all levels behaviours meet specified standards.

# Internal controls

# Operations controls

As a first line of defense in risk management, all departments and divisions are responsible for identifying and assessing the risks of their work processes, and for developing appropriate controls to ensure the HKMA’s day-to-day operations are proper.

# Corporate risk management

Risk management is also conducted at the corporate level. The Risk Committee, chaired by the Chief Executive of the HKMA, is one of the cornerstones of the institution’s risk management framework.

The risk committee reviews and reports on potential and new risks identified by each department, as well as whether related controls and mitigating strategies are sufficient, and establishes appropriate follow-up action.

# Internal audit

The HKMA’s internal audits department independently assesses the governance procedures, risk management and control measures of different departments to determine their adequacy and effectiveness, and issues recommendations for improvement.

# external audit

According to section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the financial statements of the Exchange Fund are audited by the Audit Commission of the Hong Kong SAR Government. The Audit Commission does not charge costs for this service. The audited financial statements of the Exchange Fund are published in the HKMA annual report.

# Economic and financial environment

Hong Kong’s economy recorded moderate growth in 2024, mainly driven by a rebound in merchandise exports as external demand improved and the global technology cycle recovered. The labor market remained resilient, and inflation remained moderate as external price pressures further eased. The Hong Kong stock market rebounded significantly, while the property market remained largely soft due to market sentiment being pressured by continued high interest rates. Given the escalating international trade tensions, Hong Kong’s economy is expected to face a challenging external environment in 2025. However, mainland China’s proactive launch of economic stimulus measures, together with the multifaceted support provided to local enterprises, are expected to consolidate business confidence. Hong Kong will continue to strengthen international collaboration and deepen regional cooperation.

# Economic review

# Real economic activity

Hong Kong’s economy experienced moderate growth in 2024. Real Gross Domestic Product, following a 3.2% increase in 2023, rose by 2.5% year on year in 2024 (Table 1 and Chart 1). On the external front, merchandise exports rebounded to positive growth, driven by improving external demand and the recovery of the global technology cycle, becoming a major impetus for overall economic growth. Exports of services also grew further, supported by the continued recovery of inbound tourism, as well as a significant increase in cross-border finance and fundraising activities in the second half of the year. However, as imports of services rose significantly due to continued growth in outbound tourism, this offset the positive effect of exports of services on overall economic growth. Domestically, private consumption expenditure softened somewhat due to changes in the consumption patterns of local residents. Conversely, increased property transactions and an improved business atmosphere, as monetary conditions were gradually relaxed, led to a slight increase in overall investment expenditure.

# Inflation and the labour market

Despite newly signed residential rental income gradually increasing, local cost pressures remain broadly manageable, together with diminishing external price pressures, keeping local inflation moderate in 2024 (Chart 2). For the year as a whole in 2024, the basic and overall inflation rates were 1.1% and 1.7% respectively.

The labour market demonstrated robust performance in 2024, with the unemployment rate remaining low at between 2.9% and 3.1% throughout the year (Figure 3). Total employment numbers (Figure 3) have gradually increased since the first quarter, and the labour force has also grown, reflecting a broadly stable balance between labour demand and supply. Simultaneously, with the continued economic growth, nominal wages and labour income both recorded resilient growth. Furthermore, the Government announced in the 2024 Policy Report that it would further enhance Hong Kong’s talent attraction Scheme to alleviate manpower shortages in various industries, and by attracting more young people, inject new impetus into the local population.

# Stock market

The Hong Kong stock market showed a significant turnaround in 2024 following a substantial rebound since mid-September. Specifically, with the US Federal Reserve cutting interest rates and the Mainland launching proactive economic stimulus measures, market sentiment improved significantly, driving the Hang Seng Index to a year-to-date high of 23,100 points on Oct 7, closing at that level (Figure 4). However, the US presidential election held in early November triggered concerns about the global economic prospects and the pace of the Federal Reserve’s relaxation of monetary policy, leading to a slight pullback in the Hong Kong stock market. Despite this, the Hang Seng Index closed at 20,060 points at the end of the year, a substantial increase of 17.7% compared to the end of 2023, ending a streak of annual declines over four years.

# property market

The residential property market was generally soft in the first three months of 2024, but showed signs of stabilization in the fourth quarter. With the support of relaxed related policy measures at the end of February and mid-October, as well as the beginning of the interest rate cut cycle in September, the whole year’s residential transactions surged by 23.5% from a record-low of 43,002 transactions in 2023 to 53,099 transactions in 2024. However, persistently high mortgage interest rates and accumulated inventory in the primary market continued to put downward pressure on property prices. As a result, property prices declined by 7.1% year on year in 2024, and housing affordability was also slightly improved, although it remained tight. The non-residential property market remained soft. Among them, the vacancy rate of office buildings remained high amid robust supplies, while retail shops faced challenges brought about by changes in the consumption patterns of visitors and local residents.

# economic prospects

# Economic environment

Given the heightened trade tensions, which are likely to disrupt international trade and capital flows, Hong Kong’s economy is expected to face a challenging external environment in 2025. However, various related authorities and the banking sector continue to provide multifaceted support, which should enhance the resilience of local enterprises. Mainland China is proactively launching economic stimulus measures and has also achieved significant breakthroughs in cutting-edge technology, which should also boost business confidence. At the same time, Hong Kong will further deepen regional cooperation and accelerate linkages with emerging markets. Furthermore, with Mainland authorities’ favorable tourism policies for Hong Kong and the Government’s dedication to boosting Hong Kong’s tourism industry, inbound tourism is expected to grow further.

# Inflation and the labour market

Local inflation is expected to remain moderate in 2025. As rising rental income gradually passes through to consumer prices, local costs may face slight pressure. However, despite heightened global economic uncertainties, external price pressures should remain mild. On the other hand, the labour market may face challenges as trade tensions increase. However, various talent attraction schemes should help continue to develop a quality talent pool, providing support for long-term economic development.

# Banking sector performance

Hong Kong’s banking sector remains resilient in 2024, with banks’ capital and liquidity both robust. Despite the challenging macroeconomic environment, credit risks facing the banking sector increased during the year, but the overall asset quality of banks remains manageable. Driven by gains from investments held for trading and increasing fees and commission income, retail banking profit grew compared to 2023.

# Asset quality

The banking sector’s sector-specific classified loan ratio rose from 1.57% at the end of 2023 to 1.96% at the end of 2024, while the ratio of delinquent and restructured loans increased from 1.24% to 1.55% during the same period (Figure 5). The increase in the sector-specific classified loan ratio was mainly due to downgrades in the loan ratings of some Mainland real estate developers, as well as local small and medium-sized developers and investors. However, the sector-specific classified loan ratio for Mainland China-related loans decreased from 2.58% at the end of 2023 to 2.38% at the end of 2024. Banks’ loan loss reserves remained sufficient. As at the end of 2024, the banking credit provisioning coverage ratio (i.e., credit provisioning and sector-specific classified loan ratio) was about 65%. If the value of collateral is deducted from the outstanding balance of bad debts, the adjusted banking credit provisioning coverage ratio is approximately 145%. At the same time, the delinquency ratios for residential mortgage loans and credit card loans at the end of 2024 remained at low levels, at 0.11% and 0.35% respectively (Figure 6).

# Profit trend

Retail banking’s overall profit before tax increased by 8.4% in 2024, while the average return on assets after tax for the same period rose from 0.88% to 0.93% (Figure 7). Profit growth was mainly due to gains from investments held for trading (+97.0%) and increased fee and commission income (+15.4%), but part of the increase was offset by a decrease in net interest income (–5.2%). The net interest margin of retail banking narrowed from 1.67% in 2023 to 1.52% in 2024 (Figure 8). At the same time, the cost-to-income ratio of retail banking rose slightly from 38.9% in 2023 to 39.2% in 2024 (Figure 9).

# Balance sheet trends

The banking sector’s balance sheet expanded by 4.3% in 2024, mainly due to an increase in transferable debt instruments (+13.4%). Due to still-high borrowing costs, loan demand was suppressed, and the total loan amount decreased by 2.8% in 2024. Among these, loans used in Hong Kong and those used outside Hong Kong decreased by 2.1% and 5.7% respectively, while trade finance increased by 4.6%. Related loans to Mainland China decreased by 8.7% in 2024.

Regarding the liability side of the balance sheet, the total amount of deposits increased by 7.1% in 2024, compared to an increase of 5.1% in 2023. Due to a decrease in the total amount of loans and an increase in the total amount of deposits, the overall loan-to-deposit ratio decreased from 62.8% at the end of 2023 to 57.0% at the end of 2024 (Figure 10).

# Capital adequacy ratio

The banking sector maintains robust capital in 2024. At the end of 2024, the consolidated total capital ratio of locally incorporated authorized institutions was 21.8%, compared to 21.1% for the previous year; the primary capital ratio was 19.9% (Chart 11). Both are well above the related International minimum requirements. The Basel III leverage ratio was 8.0% at the end of 2024 (Chart 12).

# 貨幣穩定

儘管美國貨幣政策走向、環球增長前景及地緣政治局勢緊張存在不明朗因素港元外匯及貨幣市場繼續保持暢順有序。港元匯率在2024年首四個月回軟，然後在年內其餘時間轉強。在聯繫匯率制度下，香港銀行同業拆息大致跟隨美元利率的走勢，同時亦受本地供求情況影響。作為香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石，聯繫匯率制度一直展現強大抵禦外來衝擊的能力。

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：

- 負債證明書（為三間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）；
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣；
- 設於金管局的結算戶口結餘總額（即總結餘）；及
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

表1 貨幣基礎

金管局透過自動利率調節機制及履行兌換保證的堅決承諾來維持港元匯率的穩定。當強方（或弱方）兌換保證被觸發，金管局會應銀行要求，按每美元兌7.75港元向銀行沽出港元、買入美元（或按7.85港元買入港元、沽出美元），使總結餘增加（或減少），令港元利率下跌（或上升），從而促使港元匯率回復到7.75至7.85的兌換範圍。

# 2024年回顧

# 匯率穩定

在2024年首四個月，港元隨着流動性回軟而稍為轉弱。在4月下旬至5月中期間，主要在股息相關資金需求及股票市場交投活躍的支持下，港元匯率轉強。在8月初，由於市場一度憂慮美國經濟可能出現衰退，以及預期美國聯邦儲備局將以更快及更大幅度減息，觸發套息交易平倉及港元短倉平倉，使港元轉強至兌換保證範圍的強方。港元在9月下旬進一步走強，受惠於內地公布一系列經濟刺激措施後，本港股市交投急增。港元其後於11月初稍為轉弱，部分由於本港股市的升幅有所回落，部分則由於其時美國經濟表現強勁，給予聯邦公開市場委員會空間謹慎地調低聯邦基金利率所致。其後港元在年底季節性資金需求帶動下回升。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2024年全年繼續運作正常（圖1）。

圖 1 2024年市場匯率

由於年內並無觸發兌換保證，總結餘變動不大，維持在447億港元左右。與此同時，未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由12,455億港元，稍增至13,839億港元。因此，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由2023 年底的 12,904 億港元，增加至 2024 年底的 14,287億港元（圖2）。整體貨幣基礎仍然由外匯儲備提供十足支持。

# 貨幣市場

在聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）下，香港銀行同業拆息大致跟隨美元利率走勢，當中短期拆息亦受本地供求情況影響。隨着市場對美國政策利率下調的預期逐漸升溫，香港銀行同業拆息在2024年首八個月大致回軟（圖3）。在季末季節性資金需求及股市交投活躍的推動下，香港銀行同業拆息於9月下旬收緊，隔夜拆息於季末更一度升至6厘以上。其後香港銀行同業拆息大致穩定，至年底前因流動性相對減少而上升。全年計，隔夜、一個月及三個月香港銀行同業拆息分別下跌45、69及78基點至年底時的5.65厘、4.58厘及4.37厘。

因應美國聯邦基金利率目標區間下調，基本利率下調三次，合共一個百分點（即100基點），由5.75厘下跌至4.75厘（圖3）。在零售層面，隨着美國下調政策利率，多間銀行在9月中調低最優惠貸款利率25基點，並在11月初及12月下旬分別再調低25基點及12.5基點。在此情況下，新造按揭貸款平均利率亦由2023年的4.13厘下跌至2024年12月的3.59厘。整體而言，香港貨幣市場繼續正常運作。貼現窗借貸由2023年的388億港元增至2024年的500億港元；貼現窗的使用情況未見異常。

# 聯繫匯率制度

自1983年以來，聯匯制度一直是香港金融體系的重要支柱，展現強大應對挑戰的能力。儘管美國政策利率走向存在不確定因素，以及地緣經濟碎片化，港元外匯及貨幣市場維持有序運作，反映聯匯制度穩健有效。政府亦堅決維持聯匯制度。國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）在《2024年對外部門報告》一再重申香港擁有具透明度的規則、龐大的財政及外匯儲備、穩健的金融規管與監管、靈活的經濟，以及審慎的財政架構，確保聯匯制度具公信力。

穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用。香港銀行體系繼續運作暢順，流動性及資本狀況以國際標準而言均非常充裕。為確保銀行體系具備抵禦衝擊的能力，金管局一直密切監察銀行的信用、流動性與利率風險管理，以及壓力測試結果，並維持對銀行貸款的監管。

為提高貨幣發行局帳目的透明度，自1998年10月起，外匯基金已有部分資產被指定用作支持貨幣基礎。支持比率（即支持資產相對貨幣基礎的比率）由2023年底的110.73%上升至2024年9月10日的112.65%高位，超出112.5%的觸發上限（圖4），當中主要來自投資的利息及投資按市價重估。按照外匯基金諮詢委員會批准的安排，從支持組合轉撥資產至投資組合，令支持比率於9月11日降至110.08%左右。其後支持比率大致保持穩定，於12月31日收報109.56%。在聯匯制度下，雖然已指定某些外匯基金資產作為支持組合，但外匯基金的全部資產均可用作支持港元匯率。外匯基金的龐大財政資源，加上香港穩健的銀行體系，為保障香港的貨幣及金融穩定提供強而有力的後盾。

# Currency stability

Despite uncertainties surrounding the direction of the US monetary policy, global growth prospects, and geopolitical tensions, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange and monetary market continued to operate smoothly and orderly. The Hong Kong dollar exchange rate softened in the first four months of 2024, and then strengthened for the rest of the year. Under the linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong interbank offered rates generally followed the trend of US interest rates, while also being affected by local supply and demand. As a cornerstone of Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability, the linked exchange rate system has consistently demonstrated strong resilience in withstanding external shocks.

# objective

The primary objective of Hong Kong’s monetary policy is to maintain monetary stability, that is, to ensure the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange value, to enable the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar against the US dollar in the external exchange market to remain within the range of HK$7.75 to HK$7.85 to 1 US dollar. This monetary system adopts a currency board system, requiring that the US dollar Reserves held by the Exchange Fund provide at least 100 percent support to the monetary base; if there are changes in the monetary base, US dollar Reserves shall also make corresponding increases or decreases, in order to adapt to the percentage change in the monetary base.

Currency foundation (Table 1) includes:

- Liabilities Certificate(s) of Indebtedness (provided full support for banknotes issued by three banks);
- Currency notes and coins issued by the Government;
- Aggregate Balance of clearing Account(s) held at the HKMA (i.e. Aggregate Balance); and
- Exchange Fund Bills and bonds issued by the HKMA on behalf of the Government.

Table 1 Currency foundation

The HKMA maintains the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate through an automated interest rate adjustment mechanism and its firm commitment to fulfilling the exchange Convertibility. When the strong-side (or weak-side) exchange guarantee is triggered, the HKMA will be standing ready to sell Hong Kong dollars and purchase US dollars to banks at 7.75 Hong Kong dollars per US dollar (or purchase Hong Kong dollars and sell US dollars at 7.85 Hong Kong dollars per US dollar) upon bank request, to increase (or decrease) the Aggregate Balance, causing Hong Kong dollar interest rate to fall (or rise), thereby prompting the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate to return to the exchange scope of 7.75 to 7.85.

# 2024 Year in Review

# Exchange rate stability

In the first four months of 2024, the Hong Kong dollar weakened slightly as liquidity softened. From late April to mid-May, the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate strengthened, supported by demand for dividends and vibrant trading in the stock market. In early August, the Hong Kong dollar strengthened to the strong-side of the Convertibility range, triggered by initial market concerns about a potential recession in the US and expectations that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates at a faster and more substantial pace, prompting unwinding of carry trades and short positions in the Hong Kong dollar. The Hong Kong dollar further strengthened in late September, driven by a surge in local stock trading following the announcement of a range of economic stimulus measures in Mainland China. The Hong Kong dollar then weakened slightly in early November, partly due to a moderation in the gains of the local stock market, and partly because the strong US economic performance at the time gave the Federal Open Market Committee room for prudent reductions in the Federal funds rate. Subsequently, the Hong Kong dollar rebounded under the impetus of seasonal funding demand at the end of the year. Overall, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange market continued to operate normally throughout 2024 (Figure 1).

Figure 1 2024 markets exchange rate

As there was no triggering of the exchange guarantee during the year, the Aggregate Balance remained relatively stable at around HK$447 billion. At the same time, the outstanding amount of Exchange Fund Notes and bonds increased slightly from HK$12,455 billion to HK$13,839 billion. Consequently, the Aggregate Balance and the outstanding amount of Exchange Fund Notes and bonds increased from HK$1,290.4 billion at the end of 2023 to HK$1,428.7 billion at the end of 2024 (Figure 2). The overall monetary foundation remains fully backed by foreign exchange Reserves.

Figure 2 2024 Aggregate Balance (before Discount Window activities) and outstanding Exchange Fund Bills and bonds

# Currency Market

Under the linked exchange rate system, Hong Kong’s interbank offered rates (HIBOR) generally follow the trend of US interest rates, with short-dated rates also affected by local supply and demand. As market expectations for a reduction in US policy rates gradually increase, Hong Kong’s interbank offered rates broadly softened in the first eight months of 2024 (Figure 3). Driven by end-of-quarter seasonal funds demand and vibrant stock market activity, Hong Kong’s interbank offered rates tightened in late September, with the overnight rate briefly rising above 6 percent at the end of the quarter. Thereafter, Hong Kong’s interbank offered rates were generally stable, rising before the end of the year due to a relative decrease in liquidity. For the whole year, the overnight, one-month, and three-month Hong Kong’s interbank offered rates fell by 45, 69, and 78 basis points respectively, to 5.65 percent, 4.58 percent, and 4.37 percent at year-end.

Following the downward adjustment of the US Federal funds rate target range, the base rate was lowered three times, totaling one percentage point (i.e., 100 basis points), from 5.75 percent to 4.75 percent (Figure 3). At the retail level, as the US lowered policy rates, more banks lowered their best lending rates by 25 basis points in mid-September, and further lowered them by 25 basis points and 12.5 basis points respectively in early November and late December. Under these conditions, the average interest rate for new mortgage loans also fell from 4.13 percent in 2023 to 3.59 percent in December 2024. Overall, the Hong Kong currency market continued to operate normally. Discount Window borrowing increased from HK$38.8 billion in 2023 to HK$50 billion in 2024; the usage of the Discount Window showed no abnormality.

Figure 3 2024 year Hong Kong interbank lending rate.

# Linked exchange rate System

Since 1983, the Linked Exchange Rate system has been an important pillar of Hong Kong’s financial system, demonstrating a strong ability to respond to challenges. Despite uncertainties surrounding the direction of US policy rates and geo-economic fragmentation, the Hong Kong dollar exchange and currency market has maintained orderly operations, reflecting the resilience and effectiveness of the Linked Exchange Rate system. The Government also remains firmly committed to maintaining the Linked Exchange Rate system. The International Monetary Fund (the Fund) repeatedly emphasized in its 2024 External Sector Report that Hong Kong has transparent rules, ample fiscal and foreign exchange Reserves, robust financial regulation and supervision, an agile economy, and a prudent fiscal framework, ensuring the credibility of the Linked Exchange Rate system.

A resilient banking sector plays a critical role in the smooth operations of the linked exchange rate system. Hong Kong’s banking sector continues to operate smoothly, with liquidity and capital positions being robust by international standards. To ensure the banking sector has the ability to withstand shocks, the HKMA has been closely monitoring banks’ credit, liquidity and interest rate risk management, as well as stress testing results, and maintaining supervision of bank lending.

To enhance the transparency of the Exchange Fund’s accounts, since October 1998, a portion of the Exchange Fund’s assets have been designated to support the monetary base. The support ratio (i.e., the ratio of supporting assets to the monetary base) rose from 110.73% at the end of 2023 to a high of 112.65% on September 10, 2024, exceeding the trigger limit of 112.5% (Figure 4), primarily due to interest from investments and the revaluation of investments at market prices. In accordance with arrangements approved by the Advisory Committee, assets were allocated from the supporting portfolio to the investment portfolio, bringing the support ratio down to around 110.08% on September 11. Subsequently, the support ratio remained broadly stable, closing at 109.56% on December 31. Under the Linked Exchange Rate System, although certain Exchange Fund assets have been designated as the supporting portfolio, all of the Exchange Fund’s assets can be used to support the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate. The Exchange Fund’s large financial resources, together with Hong Kong’s resilient banking sector, provide a strong backing for safeguarding Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability.

Figure 4 2024 year support ratio daily changes

# Currency issuance Committee

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee’s Currency Issuance Committee is responsible for monitoring and reviewing topics related to Hong Kong’s currency and financial stability. In 2024, the topics explored by the Currency Issuance Committee include the exposure of Hong Kong banks to non-bank financial institutions, and the implementation framework of the latest monetary policies in major advanced economies. Records of the Currency Issuance Committee meetings and the reports on the operations of the Exchange Fund System submitted to the HKMA are all published on the HKMA website.

# Hong Kong banknotes

Within the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority held 14 sessions related to the design and anti-counterfeiting features of Hong Kong banknotes, attracting more than 2,600 persons to participate, including bank teller personnel, retail establishments cashiers and students, which help enhance their knowledge and skills in identifying banknotes.

# coins collecting plan

The coin collection plan continues to be popular with residents. Details of the plan are included in the “Sustainable Banking and Finance” chapter of the “2024 Sustainable Development Report”.

# US dollar liquidity arrangements

The HKMA launched enhancements to the US dollar liquidity facility, including shortening the settlement cycle from T+1 to T+0, effective May 24. This standing liquidity facility can provide backup liquidity for licensed banks when needed, particularly given the United States’ implementation of a shortened settlement cycle to T+1 starting on May 28.

# Currency Research

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Research Centre (Research Centre) assisted by the Finance Academy published 15 research papers on currency and financial research topics of strategic importance to Hong Kong and the regional area, and through five issues of open access e-journals share research achievements with global readers. The Research Centre also published two issues of “Insights from Monetary Research”, providing the public with high-level non-technical statements of its recently published research.

Besides research work, the Research Centre organises a range of knowledge exchange activities to promote connections with different participants. Throughout the year, 31 workshops or online seminars were held for local participants to explore important currency and financial research topics. On the international level, the Academy of Finance together with the Research Centre, in collaboration with academic institutions, central banks of various countries and International Financial institutions, held four International Conferences and five workshops or round table meetings, to promote dialogue and exchange on a wide range of economic and financial affairs.

# 銀行體系穩定

儘管面對宏觀經濟挑戰及地緣政治的不確定性，香港銀行體系在2024年維持穩健。金管局迅速採取措施支援本地中小型企業，並透過風險為本監管與應變規劃保障銀行體系穩定，另又提供監管指引及支持業界應對新生風險，以提升銀行業的運作穩健性與網絡防衛韌性。為鼓勵應用金融科技，金管局推出連串跨行業項目，包括生成式人工智能「沙盒」。

金管局推出《保障消費者防詐騙約章2.0》，以加強銀行消費者保障。我們又推出「智安存」協助存款人有效保護存款，以及有關銀行無抵押消費信貸產品的冷靜期以減低衝動及過度借貸的風險。此外，金管局向銀行提供有關在面向客戶的服務中應用生成式人工智能的指引，又就二手物業買賣交易提供多一種支付安排與業界緊密合作。金管局亦透過發出數碼資產相關活動的指引、優化「跨境理財通」業務試點，以及簡化銷售投資及保險產品程序，提升客戶體驗，並同時確保投資者保障。年內完成個人信貸資料服務全面過渡至「信資通」。

金管局在香港的打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集制度方面扮演重要角色。透過提高經由反訛騙及洗黑錢情報工作組交換情報的速度及數量，與2023年相比，情報主導的可疑交易報告增加303%，促使凍結或充公的犯罪得益增加34%。有關促進銀行分享訊息以協助偵測及防止金融罪行的法例修訂的諮詢得到廣泛支持。金管局在4月根據交易監察系統專題審查結果提供指引，以及在9月推出計劃促進業界應用人工智能監察可疑活動。金管局亦與銀行業及香港警務處合作，優化「可疑帳號警示」機制及加強宣傳工作，並就防範、偵測及制止授權支付詐騙向銀行發出指引。

香港在實施包括資本充足及披露等國際監管標準方面取得良好進展。香港存款保障委員會優化了存款保障計劃的多個範疇，以加強對存款人的保障。

為確保處置機制具公信力，金管局實施處置標準，規定銀行須更新與對手方的金融合約，減低處置中的提前終止風險。此外，金管局在制定銀行的首選處置策略、應對處置可行性障礙以確保有足夠財政資源及處置中的運作持續性，以及提升處置執行能力方面均取得顯著進展。

# 目標

金管局的目標之一是促進銀行體系的安全及穩定。要達致這個目標，實有賴建立及維持具高度應對能力且能為香港經濟提供所需關鍵金融服務的金融體系。

銀行可能因其營運方式，甚或在極端情況下因失序地倒閉而影響金融體系的穩定。作為監管當局，金融管理專員在保障金融穩定方面擔當重要角色，確保銀行有能力抵禦衝擊及應對危機，以最終有助防止出現倒閉。金融管理專員負責對銀行進行審慎監管，以及認可香港的持牌銀行、有限制牌照銀行及接受存款公司（統稱「認可機構」）。

香港的審慎監管制度並非為確保「零風險」而設。事實上，作為一個處置機制當局，金融管理專員力求確保一旦有認可機構不再可持續經營，能有秩序地處理其倒閉。為此，香港已設立金融機構處置機制，金融管理專員在該機制下為認可機構的處置機制當局。為落實香港的處置機制，我們有必要制定處置規則及政策標準、進行處置規劃以排除認可機構處置可行性的障礙，以及建立金管局處置瀕臨倒閉認可機構的運作能力。為有效執行上述工作，金管局採納與國際一致及協調的方法。

金融管理專員亦負責指定及監察某些金融市場基建。金管局監察金融市場基建的目的，是促進有關基建的整體安全及效率、減低系統性風險，以及提高透明度。提升金融市場基建面對金融危機的抗震能力，能保障香港的貨幣與金融體系，避免因金融市場基建運作中斷而影響其穩定。

# 2024年回顧

# 牌照事宜

年內金管局向一間在香港成立為法團的銀行及一間在香港以外成立為法團的銀行授予銀行牌照。金管局亦核准一間在香港以外的交易商經紀成為貨幣經紀。此外，年內金管局撤銷三間持牌銀行、一間有限制牌照銀行及一間接受存款公司的認可資格。

有關香港的認可機構及本地代表辦事處的更多資訊，請參閱分別載於第311至314頁及第320至323頁的附錄及表D至F。

# 檢討銀行三級制

在2024年，金管局完成有關簡化銀行三級制至二級制的公眾諮詢，回應者普遍支持簡化建議。經考慮所收到的意見，金管局就建議提出若干新的關鍵事項，以精簡過渡過程及減少對接受存款公司現有客戶的影響。

# 「虛擬銀行」易名

此外，金管局完成有關「虛擬銀行(Virtual Bank)」易名為「數字銀行(Digital Bank)」的公眾諮詢。易名建議得到廣泛支持，金管局遂於10月修訂法定指引《數字銀行的認可》，有關建議正式生效。

# 數字銀行的檢討

在2024年完成的另一項工作是全面檢討數字銀行，檢討報告已於8月發表。有關檢討顯示數字銀行發展至今已達到在香港引入數字銀行的三項政策目標，即推動金融科技與創新、提供新的客戶體驗，以及促進普及金融。在數字銀行和傳統銀行的多樣化發展下，金管局認為現時數字銀行牌照的數量合適，現階段沒有必要在市場上引入更多新的數字銀行參與者。10月發出的修訂指引《數字銀行的認可》放寬了數項對業界的限制，包括容許數字銀行經營零售銀行業務以外的銀行業務，以及在從客戶體驗與業務策略的角度而言屬合理的情況下設立實體分行，前提是數字銀行繼續主要透過數碼渠道提供銀行服務。

# 銀行牌照費的檢討

金管局於年內完成對牌照費的檢討，並於6月提高費用水平。

# 香港的公司遷冊制度

金管局就於香港引入公司遷冊制度向政府提供支援，包括協助修訂《銀行業條例》及其附屬法例以及其他與金管局有關的法例的立法程序。

# 監管工作概覽

年內金管局共進行174次非現場審查，涵蓋範圍甚廣，包括認可機構的CAMEL評估、企業管治及風險管理。為繼續加強認可機構的風險管治水平，金管局與認可機構董事局、獨立非執行董事或董事局轄下委員會共舉行36次會議，並與認可機構及其外聘核數師共舉行38次三方聯席會議。此外，金管局對認可機構的各項業務進行現場審查，包括信用、市場及流動性風險管理方面的管治與做法。

鑑於認可機構應用科技的情況越趨普及，業務操作風險及科技風險管理是另一個監管重點。金管局亦進一步加強對認可機構氣候風險管理的監管，以提高認可機構應對氣候變化的能力。金管局在全球經濟不明朗的環境下維持金融穩定及促進經濟穩健增長等方面的工作得到肯定，獲《亞洲銀行家》雜誌(The AsianBanker)評選為「亞太區最佳宏觀經濟監管機構」(BestMacroeconomic Regulator in Asia Pacific)。

助理總裁（銀行監理）朱立翹女士（中）代表金管局領取《亞洲銀行家》雜誌頒發的「亞太區最佳宏觀經濟監管機構獎項

在操守監管方面，金管局對認可機構的證券、投資產品、信託、保險及強制性公積金（強積金）相關業務，以及消費者保障事項進行現場審查，並以專題評估作為配合，以審視新的項目或被評估為屬較高風險的範疇。

# 信用風險

# 信貸增長及資產質素

2024年貸款總額減少2.8%，2023年的跌幅為3.6%。表2列載各類貸款及墊款的增長情況。2024年內地相關貸款總額減少8.7%至38,590億港元（表3）。

鑑於利率仍然高企、部分內地房地產發展商的債務問題還未完全緩解，以及本地商業房地產市場疲弱，金管局在2024年繼續密切監察認可機構的資產質素及評估其信用風險管理手法。年內銀行體系的資產質素持續面對壓力，但風險形勢仍屬可控。銀行體系的特定分類貸款比率於2024年底為1.96%，高於2023年底的1.57%，而同期內地相關貸款的特定分類貸款比率則由2.58%下降至2.38%。

年內金管局進行專題評估，檢視認可機構的信用風險管理，當中重點包括對較易受影響行業的風險承擔、對私人銀行及財富管理客戶的有抵押貸款、無抵押零售貸款、對香港境外業務的信用風險的監察，以及對非銀行金融機構的風險承擔。

# 支持本地中小企

中小企是香港經濟的重要基石，金管局一直密切關注它們獲取銀行融資的情況。自金管局與銀行業於2019年成立「銀行業中小企貸款協調機制」（中小企協調機制）以來，合共推出多輪中小企支援措施，包括「預先批核還息不還本」計劃，協助中小企渡過新冠疫情期間的困境。

在2024年，金管局與銀行業推出更多措施，支持經營情況因經濟轉型而仍然面對挑戰的中小企，並協助中小企持續發展和升級轉型。

# Banking sector stability

Despite facing macroeconomic challenges and geopolitical uncertainties, Hong Kong’s banking sector remained resilient in 2024. The HKMA swiftly took measures to support local small and medium-sized enterprises, and through risk-based regulation and contingency planning, ensured the stability of the banking sector, while also providing regulatory guidance and supporting industry practitioners to respond to new risks, to enhance the operational soundness and cyber resilience of the banking industry. To encourage the application of financial technology, the HKMA launched a series of cross-sectoral projects, including a “Sandbox” for Generative Artificial Intelligence.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has launched the “Protecting Consumers from Scams Charter 2.0” to enhance consumer protection for banking customers. We have also launched “Smart Deposit” to assist depositors in effectively protecting their deposits, as well as a cooling-off period for unsecured consumer credit products to reduce the risk of impulsive and excessive borrowing. In addition, the HKMA provides guidance to banks on applying Generative Artificial Intelligence in customer-facing services, and is working closely with the industry to provide an additional payment arrangement for secondary property transactions. The HKMA also enhances customer experience by issuing guidance on digital asset-related activities, optimising the Wealth Management Connect Pilot Scheme, and streamlining the procedures for selling investment and insurance products, while ensuring investor protection. The full transition of personal credit reference services to “CreditInfo” will be completed within the year.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority plays a key role in Hong Kong’s anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing regime. By enhancing the speed and volume of intelligence sharing through the Anti-Money Laundering and Counter-Terrorist Financing Intelligence Group, intelligence-led suspicious transaction reporting increased by 303% compared to 2023, leading to a 34% increase in proceeds frozen or confiscated from criminal activity. Consultation on legislative changes to promote banks sharing information to assist in the detection and prevention of financial crime received widespread support. In April, the HKMA provided guidance based on the findings of a targeted review of transaction monitoring systems, and in September launched a Scheme to promote the application of Artificial Intelligence by the industry to monitor suspicious activity. The HKMA also collaborated with the banking sector and the Hong Kong Police Force to enhance the “suspicious account alert” mechanism and strengthen publicity efforts, and issued guidance to banks on preventing, detecting and disrupting authorized payment scams.

Hong Kong has made good progress in implementing International regulatory standards including capital adequacy and disclosure etc. The Hong Kong Deposit Protection Committee has enhanced various areas of the deposit protection Scheme to strengthen protection for depositors.

To ensure a credible resolution mechanism, the Monetary Authority implements resolution standards, requiring banks to update financial contracts with counterparties, reducing the risk of early termination during resolution. Furthermore, significant progress has been made in formulating banks’ preferred resolution strategies, responding to barriers to resolvability to ensure adequate financial resources and continued operations during resolution, and enhancing resolution execution capabilities.

# objective

One of the HKMA’s objectives is to promote the safety and stability of the banking sector. To achieve this objective, it is essential to developed and maintain a financial system with a high degree of resilience and capable of providing the critical financial services needed for the Hong Kong economy.

Banks may affect the stability of the financial system due to their operational method(s), or even due to disorderly failure in extreme cases. As a supervisory authority, the Monetary Authority plays an important role in safeguarding financial stability, ensuring banks have the resilience to withstand shocks and respond to crises, ultimately helping to prevent failure. The Monetary Authority is responsible for prudential supervision of banks, as well as authorization of licensed banks in Hong Kong, restricted license banks and deposit taking companies (collectively named “authorized institutions”).

Hong Kong’s prudential regulatory regime is not designed to ensure “zero risk”. In fact, as a resolution authority, the Monetary Authority seeks to ensure that, should an authorized institution become non-viable, its failure can be resolved in an orderly manner. To this end, Hong Kong has established a corporate resolution mechanism, with the Monetary Authority serving as the resolution authority for authorized institutions under that mechanism. To implement Hong Kong’s resolution mechanism, it is necessary to determine resolution rules and policy standards, conduct resolution planning to remove barriers to the resolvability of authorized institutions, and build the HKMA’s capabilities to operate the resolution of authorized institutions nearing failure. To effectively carry out the above work, the HKMA adopts methods consistent with and coordinate with international standards.

The Monetary Authority is also responsible for designating and monitoring certain financial market infrastructures. The HKMA’s monitoring of financial market infrastructures aims to promote the overall safety and efficiency of the related infrastructures, reduce systemic risks, and enhance transparency. Enhancing the resilience of financial market infrastructures to financial crises can protect Hong Kong’s monetary and financial system(s), and prevent disruptions to their operations from affecting its stability.

# 2024 Year in Review

# License matters.

Within the year, the HKMA granted banking licenses to a bank established as a corporation in Hong Kong and a bank established as a corporation outside of Hong Kong. The HKMA also approved a broker outside of Hong Kong to become a currency broker. In addition, during the year, the HKMA revoked the authorization of three licensed banks, one bank with restricted licenses, and one deposit-taking company.

For additional information related to Hong Kong’s authorized institutions and Local offices, See appendices and Table D to F, which are included on pages 311 to 314 and 320 to 323 respectively.

# Reviews of the three-level banking system.

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority completed related Public consultation on streamlining the three-tiered banking system to a two-tiered system, and respondents generally Support the streamlining recommendations. After considering the feedback received, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has put forward several new critical matters regarding the recommendations, in order to achieve streamlining of the transition process and reduce the impact on existing customers of Deposittaking companies.

# "Virtual banks" are rebranded.

In addition, the HKMA completed related public consultation on renaming “Virtual Bank” to “Digital Bank”. The renaming proposal received widespread support, and the HKMA therefore revised the statutory guidance “Authorization of Digital Banks” in Oct, with the related recommendations officially taking effect.

# Reviews of digital banks.

Another task completed in 2024 was a comprehensive review of digital banks, with the review report published in August. The review shows that the development of digital banks has, to date, achieved the three policy objectives of introducing digital banks in Hong Kong, namely to promote financial technology and innovation, provide new customer experiences, and promote financial inclusion. With the diversified development of both digital banks and traditional banks, the HKMA believes that the current volume of digital bank licenses is appropriate and there is no necessary to introduce additional new digital bank participants into the market at this stage. Amendments to the guidance “Authorization of Digital Banks” issued in October relaxed several restrictions on the industry, including allowing digital banks to operate banking business beyond retail banking, and to establish physical branches where reasonable from the perspective of customer experience and business strategies, provided that digital banks continue to primarily provide banking services through digital channels.

# Reviews of bank license fees.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority completed a review of license fees within the year and increased the costs level in June.

# Hong Kong’s company migration System

The HKMA provides support to the Government regarding the introduction of a company migration regime in Hong Kong, including assisting with the legislative procedures for amendments to the banking legislation and its subsidiary legislation, as well as other legislation related to the HKMA.

# Regulatory work overview

Throughout the year, the HKMA conducted 174 non-site examinations covering a wide scope, including CAMEL assessment of authorized institutions, corporate governance and risk management. To further enhance the risk governance levels of authorized institutions, the HKMA held 36 meetings in total with the boards of directors of authorized institutions, independent non-executive directors or committees under the boards, and co-chaired 38 tripartite meetings with authorized institutions and their external auditors. In addition, the HKMA conducted on-site examinations of various business tasks of authorized institutions, including governance and practices in credit, market and liquidity risk management.

Given the increasing prevalence of technology adoption by authorized institutions, risk management of business operations and technology risks is another supervisory priority. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has also further strengthened its supervisory work on climate risk management by authorized institutions, to enhance their ability to respond to climate change. The HKMA’s work in maintaining financial stability and promoting robust economic growth amid a global economic uncertain environment has been recognized, and it was selected by *The Asian Banker* magazine as “Best Macroeconomic Regulator in Asia Pacific”.

Assistant Chief Executive (Bank Supervision) Ms. Zhu Liqiao (in) represents the Hong Kong Monetary Authority to receive the “Asia-Pacific Best Macroeconomic Regulatory Institution Award” presented by The Asian Banker magazine.

In terms of supervisory conduct, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority conducts on-site examination of the securities, investment products, trusts, insurance and Mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) related business of authorized institutions, as well as consumer protection issues, and uses thematic assessments to ensure compliance, to review new projects or areas assessed as high risks.

Focusing on operational resilience, additional supervisory work includes an investigation by the HKMA and authorization of institutions to conduct self-assessment to review implementation progress and identify areas for improvement, as well as extensive outreach activities at both bilateral and industry levels regarding the development of frameworks and practices.
b. Furthermore, supervisory work focuses on assessing authorized institutions’ approval and continued risk management strategies and practices for specific credit portfolios, such as those for commercial properties and small and medium-sized enterprise loans.

# Credit risks

# Credit growth and asset quality.

In 2024, the total loan amount decreased by 2.8%, while the decline in 2023 was 3.6%. Table 2 sets out the growth situation of various types of loans and advances. In 2024, the total amount of Mainland-related loans decreased by 8.7% to HK$385.9 billion (Table 3).

Given that policy rates remain high, debt problems of some Mainland real estate developers have not been fully alleviated, and the local commercial real estate market is soft, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to closely monitor the asset quality of authorized institutions and assess their credit risk management approaches in 2024. Throughout the year, the asset quality of the banking sector continued to face pressures, but the risk situation remained manageable. # 香港的國際金融中心地位

金管局於2024年在加強香港作為具全球競爭力的國際金融中心的地位方面取得重要進展。

金管局與內地及香港有關當局合作，推出一系列措施，共同深化及擴展香港與內地金融市場的互聯互通，包括優化「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」；擴大金管局人民幣流動資金安排及「北向互換通」的合資格抵押品範圍；優化「北向互換通」；以及優化一級流動性提供行安排。這些措施有助強化香港的門戶角色，並鞏固其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位

金管局在鞏固香港金融平台的競爭力方面亦取得良好進展，涵蓋債券發行、資產及財富管理、綠色和可持續金融，以及企業財資中心等範疇。為宣傳香港的金融服務，金管局加強面向海外及內地持份者的市場推廣工作，讓大家充分認識香港金融體系的穩健及其帶來的機遇。第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」及多項其他盛事成功舉辦，不僅有助提升香港作為主要國際金融中心的形象，更製造正面的漣漪效應。金管局積極參與多個國際及區內的央行及監管組織，繼續對維持金融穩定及促進金融市場發展的全球工作作出貢獻。

金管局在「金融科技2025」 策略的各個範疇均取得顯著進展，包括央行數碼貨幣及數據基建。

快速支付系統「轉數快」的登記數目及交易量繼續穩步增長，於2024年底達到1,580萬個登記，全年平均每日處理港元即時交易增至165萬宗。金管局正與中國人民銀行緊密合作，推動落實香港「轉數快」與內地網上支付跨行清算系統互聯，實現跨境支付。

# 概覽

在2024年，金管局繼續致力提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。

金管局擴展及優化香港與內地間的互聯互通機制，有助鞏固香港作為內地與國際金融市場間的橋樑角色。年內，多項有關「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」（「跨境理財通」）的優化措施出台，便利粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）個人投資者進行跨境投資。於2月，金管局將中華人民共和國財政部（國家財政部）發行的在岸國債和內地政策性銀行發行的政策性金融債納入人民幣流動資金安排的合資格抵押品名單。於7月，兩地相關部門公布進一步支持境外投資者使用通過「債券通」持有的在岸債券作為「北向互換通」交易的履約抵押品，並於2025年1月實施。此外，「北向互換通」於年內進行優化，增加投資者在對沖策略和管理投資組合方面的靈活性及效率。

在2024年，香港的離岸人民幣業務穩健增長。金管局推出一級流動性提供行安排的優化措施，包括增加提供行數目及擴大安排規模。於年底前，香港人民幣即時支付結算系統的夜間跨境服務能力提升，以更好應付全球各地對跨境人民幣支付的需要。

金管局推出大灣區金融合作下的多項利民便商措施，包括促進企業跨境融資的跨境徵信互通業務試點，以及便利香港居民在大灣區置業的跨境匯款支付安排。

金管局繼續致力提升香港整體金融平台的競爭力。具體而言，為增強香港作為首選基金管理中心及家族辦公室業務樞紐的吸引力，金管局與政府及金融業緊密合作，締造更便利的稅務及監管環境。此外，金管局透過Evergreen項目發行第二批代幣化債券，並推出「EvergreenHub」一站式數碼債券知識庫和「數碼債券資助計劃」，繼續推動香港債券市場創新。於10月，金管局公布「可持續金融行動計劃」，訂明進一步鞏固香港作為區內綠色和可持續金融樞紐的具體目標。

另一方面，金管局繼續加強市場拓展工作，向海外及內地持份者介紹香港的金融服務。金管局在11月舉辦第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」。峰會為期三日，主題為「在變局中前航」，雲集全球各地金融業界翹楚分享各自獨到的觀點。峰會先由國務院副總理何立峰先生作開幕主題演講，接着是三間內地金融監管機構的分享環節，以及由國際金融領袖參與的專題討論。峰會共匯聚350多位來自超過120間國際金融機構的領袖參與，充分體現國際金融界對香港的支持和信心。

年內金管局亦舉辦各項其他研討會及會議，包括：

- 於9月與迪拜金融服務管理局合辦聯合氣候金融會議；
- 於10月與全球風險管理專業人士協會合辦第15屆全球風險論壇；
- 於10月亦與國際結算銀行合辦國際金融研討會；及
- 於12月舉辦金融穩定理事會全體會議，是自2016年以來首次在亞洲舉行的同類會議，匯聚超過50個國家財政金融機關及12個國際標準制定機構的領袖和高級官員。

年內金管局亦積極加強與其他地區的雙邊聯繫。於12月，金管局分別與阿拉伯聯合酋長國中央銀行（阿聯酋央行）及沙特中央銀行（沙特央行）在香港舉行雙邊會議，促進中東與亞洲地區之間的投資及金融市場聯繫。金管局與阿聯酋央行簽署諒解備忘錄，建立兩地債務資本市場基建的互聯互通，並促進跨境債務證券發行及投資活動。在此之前，金管局於10月訪問卡塔爾多哈，加強兩地金融服務領域的合作。

此外，金管局於12月舉行第七次香港與瑞士金融合作對話，討論內容涵蓋區內及本地的前景與政策挑戰，以及可持續金融、金融科技與市場互聯互通領域的最新發展及潛在合作空間。

金管局分別於1月及5月訪問泰國和馬來西亞，與中央銀行、金融機構和企業會面，推廣香港作為國際金融中心的地位，並進一步加強雙邊金融聯繫和合作。重點領域之一是推廣使用人民幣和本地貨幣作跨境投資和貿易結算，以及香港的競爭優勢。

在國際層面，金管局積極參與中央銀行領域的事務，並繼續在多個區內及國際委員會擔當領導角色。金管局現為巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下政策及標準小組和金融穩定理事會轄下亞洲區域諮詢小組的聯席主席，另又擔任金融穩定理事會轄下金融創新網絡聯席主席（至2024年7月止）。金管局亦為國際結算銀行轄下主要新興市場經濟體行長會議和金融穩定理事會轄下加密資產框架同業評審小組的主席。在2018至2024年間，金管局一直連任東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP)轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

金管局金融科技促進辦公室與各銀行部門繼續實施「金融科技2025」策略，促進業界廣泛採用金融科技，並提升香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位。年內推行的主要措施包括：

- 進一步推動銀行在五個主要範疇的金融科技應用，包括財富科技、保險科技、綠色科技、人工智能及分布式分類帳技術；
- 推動央行數碼貨幣的工作，以了解其效益及潛在的應用場景，包括：
    - 推進「多種央行數碼貨幣跨境網絡」(mBridge)項目，以改善跨境支付；
    - 進一步研究在香港發行「數碼港元」(e-HKD)的可行性；及
    - 開始探索以央行數碼貨幣支持香港代幣化市場的發展；
- 透過「商業數據通」便利中小企借貸；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；及
- 推動更廣泛使用快速支付系統「轉數快」。

「轉數快」的使用在2024年繼續增加，登記數目與交易量在過去六年穩步上升。截至2024年底，「轉數快」登記數目增至1,580萬個，全年每日平均交易宗數較上年上升33%。除個人對個人支付及商業支付穩步增長外，透過「轉數快」繳付政府帳單、支付予商戶及為儲值支付工具電子錢包或銀行帳戶增值持續增加，是帶動「轉數快」交易量持續增長的主要原因。

為確保本地零售支付業的安全及效率，金管局根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）監察六個指定零售支付系統，並監管15項持牌儲值支付工具（其中四項由持牌銀行發行）。年內金管局繼續與業界緊密合作，因應詐騙風險上升加強管控措施及保障消費者。

財經事務及庫務局與金管局就在香港實施穩定幣發行人監管制度的立法建議，於2月完成為期兩個月的公眾諮詢後，於7月聯合發表諮詢總結，並於12月將《穩定幣條例草案》提交立法會審議。為更了解穩定幣發行人的業務模式，並制定適切的監管制度，金管局亦推出穩定幣發行人「沙盒」，並於7月公布三間進入「沙盒」的參與機構。與此同時，金管局繼續積極參與國際組織在數碼資產相關課題（包括穩定幣及代幣化）的工作，確保相關監管框架符合國際標準及最佳做法。

# Hong Kong’s international financial centre status

The HKMA has made significant progress in 2024 in strengthening Hong Kong’s position as a global financial centre.

The HKMA, together with related authorities in the Mainland and Hong Kong, has launched a range of measures to jointly deepen and expand connectivity between Hong Kong and the Mainland’s financial markets, including enhancements to the “Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area Cross-boundary Wealth Management Connect”; expanding the scope of eligible collateral under the HKMA’s RMB Liquidity arrangements and the “Northbound Bond Connect”; optimising the “Northbound Bond Connect”; and enhancing Primary liquidity providing arrangements. These measures help reinforce Hong Kong’s gateway role and underpin its status as a global hub for offshore renminbi business.

The HKMA has also made good progress in consolidating Hong Kong’s financial centre’s competitiveness, covering bond issuance, asset and wealth management, green and sustainable finance, and corporate treasury centres, among other areas. To promote Hong Kong’s financial services, the HKMA has strengthened its market outreach to overseas and Mainland stakeholders, ensuring they have a full understanding of the soundness of Hong Kong’s financial system and the opportunities it brings. The third edition of the ‘Investment Summit’ and various other major events were successfully held, not only helping to enhance Hong Kong’s image as a leading international financial centre, but also creating a positive ripple effect. The HKMA actively participates in various international and regional central banks and regulatory organisations, continuing to contribute to the global work of maintaining financial stability and promoting financial market development.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has made significant progress in all areas of the “Financial Tech 2025” strategy, including central bank digital currency and data infrastructure.

The Faster Payment System “Faster Payment” registration numbers and turnover continued to grow steadily, reaching 15.8 million registrations at the end of 2024, with the Average daily handling of Hong Kong dollar real-time transactions increasing to 1.65 million items for the whole year. The HKMA is currently working closely with the People’s Bank of China to promote the implementation of the linkage between the Hong Kong “Faster Payment” and the Mainland cross-border bank-to-bank clearing system, achieving cross-border Payment.

# Overview

In 2024, the HKMA continues its efforts to enhance Hong Kong’s competitiveness as an International Financial Centre.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has expanded and enhanced the connectivity mechanisms between Hong Kong and the Mainland, which helps to consolidate Hong Kong’s role as a bridge between the Mainland and international financial markets. Throughout the year, a number of enhancements to the “Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area Wealth Management Connect” ( “WMC”) were implemented, facilitating cross-border investment for individual investors in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area (Greater Bay Area). In February, the HKMA included onshore national debt issued by the Ministry of Finance of the People’s Republic of China and policy financial debt issued by Mainland policy banks in the list of eligible collateral under the RMB Liquidity arrangements. In July, relevant departments on both sides announced further support for offshore investors to use onshore bonds held through “Bond Connect” as collateral for “Northbound Swap Connect” transactions, to be implemented in January 2025. In addition, “Northbound Swap Connect” underwent enhancements during the year, increasing the agility and efficiency of investors in hedging strategies and managing investment portfolios.

In 2024, Hong Kong’s offshore renminbi business grew robustly. The HKMA launched enhancements to the Primary Liquidity Providing Facility arrangements, including increasing the number of providing institutions and expanding the facility size. Before the end of the year, the resilience of Hong Kong’s real-time gross settlement system for overnight cross-border payments will be enhanced to better meet the demand for cross-border renminbi payments worldwide.

The HKMA launched a number of facilitative measures under Financial cooperation in the Greater Bay Area, including a pilot scheme for cross-boundary credit information exchange to promote cross-border financing for enterprises, and arrangements facilitating payments for Hong Kong residents buying properties in the Greater Bay Area.

The HKMA continues to strive to enhance the competitiveness of Hong Kong’s overall financial platform. Specifically, to strengthen Hong Kong’s appeal as a preferred fund Management Centre and family office business hub, the HKMA is working closely with the Government and the financial sector to create a more facilitated tax and regulatory environment. In addition, the HKMA is continuing to promote innovation in the Hong Kong bond market by issuing the second batch of tokenized bonds through the Evergreen project and launching the “EvergreenHub” one-stop digital bond knowledge repository and the “Digital Bond Funding Scheme”. In Oct, the HKMA announced the “Sustainable Finance Action Plan”, provides specific objectives for further consolidating Hong Kong’s position as a regional green and sustainable finance hub.

On the other hand, the HKMA continues to strengthen market expansion work, to promote Hong Kong’s financial services to overseas and the Mainland stakeholders. The HKMA held the third Investment Summit in Nov, which lasts three days, with the theme of “Sailing Ahead Amidst Change”, bringing together leaders from the global financial community to share their unique perspectives. The summit began with an opening keynote speech by Vice Premier He Lifeng, followed by sharing sessions from three Mainland financial regulatory agencies, and a special discussion with International leaders. The summit gathered more than 350 leaders from over 120 international financial institutions, fully demonstrated the support and confidence of the international financial community for Hong Kong.

Within the year, the HKMA also held various other workshops and meetings, including:

- Co-organise a Joint Climate Finance Conference with the Dubai International Financial Centre in Sep;
- Co-host the 15th Global Risk Forum with the Global Association of Risk Professionals in Oct;
- Also organise an International Financial seminar with the Bank for International Settlements in Oct; and
- Hold a plenary meeting of the Financial Stability Board in Dec, which is the first such meeting held in Asia since 2016, bringing together leaders and senior officials from financial authorities of more than 50 countries and 12 international standards-setting institutions.

Throughout the year, the HKMA also actively strengthened bilateral linkages with other regions. In December, the HKMA held bilateral meetings in Hong Kong with the Central Bank of the United Arab Emirates (the UAE Central Bank) and the Saudi Central Bank (SAMA), to promote investment and Financial Market connectivity between the Middle East and Asia regions. The HKMA signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the UAE Central Bank to developed cross-border debt capital markets Infrastructure, and promote cross-border debt Securities issuance and investment activities. Prior to this, in October, the HKMA visited Doha, Qatar, to strengthen cooperation in the two jurisdictions’ financial services areas.

In addition, the HKMA held the seventh Hong Kong-Switzerland Financial collaboration dialogue in December, with discussions covering regional and local prospects and policy challenges, as well as the latest developments and potential collaboration space in sustainable finance, financial technology and market connectivity.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority sent representatives to Thailand and Malaysia for interviews in Jan and 5, meeting with central banks, financial institutions and enterprises to promote Hong Kong’s status as an international financial centre, and to further strengthen bilateral financial links and co-operation. A key area of focus is the promotion of using Renminbi and local currency for cross-border investment and trade settlement, as well as Hong Kong’s competitive advantages.

At the international level, the HKMA actively participates in central banking affairs and continues to play a leadership role in various regional and international committees. The HKMA currently co-chairs the Policy and Standards Group under the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision (Basel Committee) and the Asia Regional Consultative Group under the Financial Stability Board (FSB), and also serves as co-chair of the FSB’s Innovative Use Cases Taskforce (until July 2024). The HKMA also chairs the meetings of Governors of Major Emerging Market Economies under the Bank for International Settlements and the Peer Review Group for Crypto-asset Frameworks under the FSB. From 2018 to 2024, the HKMA has consistently served as Chairman of the Financial Market Workstream under the East Asia and Pacific Central Banks Group (EMEAP).

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s Financial Technology Promotion Office and various bank departments continue implementing the “Financial Technology 2025” strategy, promote the widespread adoption of financial technology within the industry, and enhance Hong Kong’s status as a financial technology hub in Asia. Key measures to be implemented within the year include:

- Further promote banking application of financial technology in five key areas, including wealth tech, insurance tech, green technology, Artificial Intelligence and distributed ledger technology;
- Drive work relating to central bank digital currency to understand its benefits and potential use cases, including:

    - Further study the resolvability of issuing “Digital Hong Kong dollar” (e-HKD) in Hong Kong; and
    - Begin to explore supporting the development of a tokenized market in Hong Kong with central bank digital currency;
- Facilitate borrowing for SMEs through “Commercial Data Interchange”;
- Strengthen cross-border financial technology cooperation; and
- Promote wider use of the Faster Payment System “Faster Payment”.

“Faster Payment System” usage continued to increase in 2024, with the number of registrations and turnover steadily growing over the past six years. In addition to stable growth in person-to-person payments and Commercial payments, continued increases were seen in using “Faster Payment System” to pay government bills, make payments to merchants, and top up electronic wallets or bank accounts, which are the main reasons driving the continued growth in “Faster Payment System” turnover.

To ensure the safety and efficiency of the local retail payment sector, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) monitors six specified retail payment systems under the “Payment Systems and Stored Value Facility Ordinance” (“Payment Ordinance”) and regulates 15 licensed Stored Value Facility (SVF) tools (among which four main are issued by licensed banks). During the year, the HKMA continued to collaborate closely with the industry, following the increasing fraud risks by strengthening supervisory measures and protecting consumers.

The Financial Affairs and Treasury Bureau and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) jointly published a consultation summary in July, following the completion of a two-month public consultation in February, on legislative proposals for the supervisory and regulatory regime for stablecoin issuers in Hong Kong, and submitted the “Stablecoins Ordinance Draft” to the Legislative Council for deliberation in December. To further understand the business models of stablecoin issuers and to develop appropriate supervisory arrangements, the HKMA also launched a stablecoin issuer “Sandbox” and announced three participating institutions entering the “Sandbox” in July. At the same time, the HKMA continues to actively participate in the work of international organisations on issues related to digital assets (including stablecoins and tokenisation), ensuring that the relevant regulatory framework meets international standards and best practices.

# 儲備管理

2024年環球金融市場表現大致良好。主要經濟體錄得穩定增長，而通脹亦回落至更接近政策目標的水平。多個主要央行陸續下調政策利率，有利投資環境。2024年全年計，外匯基金錄得2,188億港元的投資收入，投資回報率為5.2%。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。金管局根據財政司司長轉授的權力及轉授權力的條款，就外匯基金的運用及投資管理向財政司司長負責。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合架構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：

(i) 保障資本；
(ii) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(iii) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(iv) 在符合上述(i)至(iii)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障外匯基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合架構及目標資產配置中反映（圖示1）。

圖示1 外匯基金的投資組合類別

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員經濟體的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產配置於較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權（包括基建）及房地產。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的目標資產配置與其他資產類別的配置，按審慎的風險管理原則及資產組合多元化策略一起制定。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，一直持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎，但未來基金屬主要個別例子，其存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的回報掛鈎，利率視乎實際資產配置而定。於2024年，投資組合與長期增長組合在未來基金的目標資產配置約為35：65。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產配置及戰略性資產配置作基礎。策略性資產配置以投資基準方式反映，亦即外匯基金為達到投資目標而可作出的長線資產配置。外匯基金以策略性配置作為指引，透過戰略性的資產配置，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際配置往往會與基準配置（亦即策略性配置）有所偏離，而實際與基準配置之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及循跡誤差限額，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產配置及定出戰略性偏離的容許範圍。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的容許範圍內管理倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 直接投資

金管局的外匯基金投資辦公室專責外匯基金的投資及相關風險管理職能。該辦公室職員負責直接管理外匯基金約70%的投資，包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分內部管理的投資組合包括環球定息市場投資，並透過不同的衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約30%的資產，包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產類別。僱用外聘投資經理的目的是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資專才為外匯基金投資，獲取可持續回報，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化及互補的投資方式，以及汲取外聘投資經理的市場心得與專門的投資知識。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

# 風險管理及監察

投資環境越趨複雜，穩健的風險管理更見重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂下嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並設立嚴謹的風險監察及合規制度。金管局為投資相關活動設有三重防線，以實施有效的風險管理及管治。金管局定期監察主要投資風險類別（包括信用、市場、流動性及業務操作風險），並設置風險管理程序，為策略性規劃及多元化投資工作提供穩健的框架。

# 負責任投資

金管局相信適度強調負責任投資及投資的可持續長期表現，可更有效達致外匯基金的投資目標，並且減低投資活動涉及的環境、社會及管治(ESG)相關風險。為積極支持負責任投資，金管局已將ESG因素融入外匯基金的投資管理過程中，其指導性原則是：當ESG投資與其他投資項目的經風險調整長期收益相若時，一般會優先考慮ESG投資。有關金管局在負責任投資方面的工作，詳見《二零二四年可持續發展報告》之「負責任投資」一章。

# 外匯基金的表現

# 2024年的金融市場

2024年環球金融市場表現大致良好。

主要股票市場於2024年升幅顯著，當中美國股市在經濟和通脹基調大致向好和人工智能熱潮背景下，首三季升幅尤其突出。不過第4季市況因憂慮通脹升溫及債息上升等而變得波動並從高位回落，投資者亦轉趨審慎。內地和香港股市方面，受惠於中央在第3季出台的一系列刺激經濟和股市的政策措施，投資者信心有所好轉。然而市場認為實體經濟增長依然不明朗的情況下，兩地股市於第4季回軟。

環球債券市場在2024年的表現亦有較大波動。儘管主要央行大致確立減息的大方向，但減息的節奏和幅度年內出現多次轉變。及至第4季，市場開始注視美國2025年的財政政策，美國國債收益率季內大幅上升，債價受壓。

貨幣市場方面，美元兌其他主要貨幣於2024年，特別是第4季，因為息口走勢和美國經濟表現相對強勁而走強。

於2024年底，外匯基金的資產總值達40,810億港元。長期增長組合投資的總市值為5,412億港元，其中私募股權為4,348億港元，房地產為1,064億港元。長期增長組合中已承擔但尚未提取作投資的總額為2,886億港元。
